dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A day in LATE AUGUST. A FIGURE on a hill top; the unpopul landscape - lush in summer, barren and bleak in winter - curving down to high chalk cliffs with the ocean beyond. GABRIEL OAK sits watching over his flock with his two DOG his face handsome if somewhat weather-beaten beneath a lo crowned felt hat. He has a quality of contentment, calm a stillness. Idly, he plays with a stone in his hand. No so but the sounds of nature. Which is why his eye is drawn towards the horizon, the so of wheels. A CART is approaching. Curious GABRIEL rises a walks closer, as the CART stops at a toll gate and the OL WAGGONER gets down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From GABRIEL’s p.o.v, an argument has broken out with the TURNPIKE KEEPER.

dialogues.speaker: WAGGONER
dialogues.text: Misses says she won’t pay more.

dialogues.speaker: TURNPIKE KEEPER
dialogues.text: Then Misses’d best turn back. Price is thrupence. The WAGGONER sighs, and goes to negotiate with his PASSEN as yet unseen. GABRIEL steps closer.

dialogues.speaker: WAGGONER
dialogues.text: Perhaps best to pay him. Be dark soon. She replies - barely heard. The WAGGONER returns.

dialogues.speaker: WAGGONER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She says she’s paid you quite enough.

dialogues.speaker: TURNPIKE KEEPER
dialogues.text: Three pence. A stand-off. Until GABRIEL arrives. He knows the GATEKEEP A local.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Let her through. It’s a woman on her own.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 2 Going through the gate, BATHSHEBA EVERDENE very briefly t to GABRIEL. If she feels gratitude, she can’t quite bring herself to express it. Pride wins out. The cart moves on.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO BLACK
dialogues.text: TITLES - ‘FAR FROM THE MADDING CROWD.’ 3 Under TITLES, a series of Wessex landscapes. - CARROW COVE on a brisk autumn day, the low sun glinting the sea. - the CLIFFS of NORCOMBE HILL facing out into the sea in grip of a winter storm. - the RIVER AXE in full flow with the melting snows of spring. - bleak EGDON HEATH in the rain, the road seeming to stre on forever. - the gloom of the GREAT FOREST, dark in its depths even the brightest summer day. - the mud and stone of ploughed fields in the VALE of BLACKMORE, awaiting planting in March. This is the stage for our story, quite remote from the re of the world. A grand landscape, sometimes beautiful, sometimes harsh - - and finally, the slope of NORCOMBE HILL on a day in LAT SEPTEMBER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATE SEPTEMBER. A chink of light opens out as the stable is pulled open. BATHSHEBA is silhouetted against the brig light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATHSHEBA leads the horse into the yard of MRS HURST’s fa small, subsistence-level but tidy and well-kept, clinging the side of the remote hill. We see her face as she greets the horse; a startlingly vi face, full of spirit and determination. She rides off.

dialogues.speaker: 7B
dialogues.text: FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - heading down to the forest that borders the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATHSHEBA finds herself in a hollow-way, a path covered b canopy of trees, too low for rider and horse to pass bene She looks one way, then the other, to ensure that she’s a then, in a single dextrous movement, then switches from s saddle to cross-saddle, tucking her dress up - some sort trousers or breaches revealed beneath. Comfortable now, s lies backwards along the horse so that her head is near i tail, her feet near its shoulders, her eyes to the sky. I an impressive performance, almost a circus trick, and she smiles in satisfaction to herself as the horse trots forw the sky showing between the low boughs. On the ground behind her, a SCARF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - towards a high vantage point. The panorama is magnifice and she smiles to herself. She urges the horse on, a wonderful rider, riding past GABRIEL without even stopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SCARF again, but now it lies on the table of GABRIEL OAK’s cottage, a neat, comfortable place. GABRIEL sits nearby, counting out money which he locks aw in a strong box. He closes his money box. His eye returns to the SCARF - EXT. GABRIEL’S COTTAGE - DAY 8 Another day. From his high vantage point, GABRIEL with hi sheep and dogs, behind him his cottage. He sees BATHSHEBA walking by, below.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Miss! In his hand, the lost SCARF. He stays proudly on top of t hill, so she has to climb the hill towards him. He hands the scarf.

dialogues.speaker: 8B
dialogues.text: FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 4

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: (out of breath) My scarf. I lost it. You must be Farmer Oak. (surprise from GABRIEL) This is your land, I must be trespassing.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: You're welcome here. Gabriel. And you are...?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I’d rather not tell you. It’s a very odd name, I try not to say it out loud.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: I’m sure you could get a new one. If you wanted. (An awkward moment, a misfire. She takes the scarf -) Forgive me, I can’t always..map my mind on my tongue.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Thank you. Farmer Oak. On BATHSHEBA as she walks away, a small smile appearing. EXT. MRS HURST’S FARM, NORCOMBE HILL - DAY 8A BATHSHEBA is milking the cows. GABRIEL is herding his she nearby, heading up to the small SHEPHERD’S HUT, a kind of CARAVAN from where he guards the sheep. A greeting between them. She steps out and looks after hi The ice melting - EXT. GABRIEL’S CARAVAN, NORCOMBE HILL - DAY 8B GABRIEL has two dogs, YOUNG GEORGE who barks and nips at flock, and OLD GEORGE who sits contentedly by BATHSHEBA. A new development. BATHSHEBA watches GABRIEL go about his work with some admiration. GABRIEL, for his part, is show off a little.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Come by, George. Come! (Returning to BATHSHEBA) He’s keen enough, Young George, but he doesn’t know when to stop. (petting OLD GEORGE) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 5

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not like this one. Been with me a long time, haven’t you?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: And what’s that one called?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: This is Old George.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: (she laughs) Of course. Old George. And GABRIEL walks away towards his caravan.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Find me amusing, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATHSHEBA is out riding once more. She stops. It’s a beautiful night, the stars framing her, steam rising from horse. From somewhere in the distance, the sound of dogs barking. Some distance away stands GABRIEL’s hut, the small buildi on wheels that he uses for shelter when watching the floc night. Smoke rises from the chimney. But something is amiss. We follow her towards the caravan. She knocks on the door no answer. She goes in and finds - INT. GABRIEL’S CARAVAN, NORCOMBE HILL - NIGHT 10 GABRIEL lies unconscious in the smoky interior. BATHSHEBA takes in the scene then leaps into action. With all her strength, she drags him upright, slaps his face.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Mr Oak! Mr Oak, wake up! Gabriel Oak! Nothing. Now she tries to haul him to her feet. But he fa a dead-weight, across her lap. This is all new to BATHSHE A man in her lap. She takes it in. To her side, a jug of milk. She takes it, throws it into his face. Gasping, dazed and confused he comes round. Looks up, see her face. She laughs with relief. GABRIEL is confused, breathless.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: What’s the matter? What is it?  11 12 13 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 6

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Nothing, since you’re not dead. I was heading home when I heard the dogs barking. (she busies herself, ventilating the hut) It's very foolish of you, Farmer. Oak. My uncle had a hut just like this, I used to play in it asa little girl and he told me, always, always keep a window open or you'll suffocate. ( - the wetness - ) I’m sorry about the milk. At least it was warm. (he attempts to stand, stumbles. Takes her HAND) Rest a moment. You know, Farmer Oak, I think I may have saved your life. Her hand in his, as GABRIEL steadies himself.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Tell me your name. I still don’t know your name.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Then find it out. My hand, Mr Oak? Somewhat reluctantly, he lets go of her hand. She walks o into the night. GABRIEL sits on the steps and watches her go. EXT. GABRIEL’S CARAVAN, NORCOMBE HILL - DAY 11 Next morning. GABRIEL is working his sheep, but his mind elsewhere. He stops working, his mind wandering. INT. GABRIEL’S CARAVAN, NORCOMBE HILL - DAY 12 GABRIEL polishes his boots, puts away his working clothes decision has been made. EXT. GABRIEL’S CARAVAN, NORCOMBE HILL - DAY 13 GABRIEL walks through his flock and finds a lamb. It has weeks early, and is the only one. He scoops the tiny thin up.  14 15 16 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 7 EXT. MRS HURST’S COTTAGE -— DAY 14 Accompanied by OLD GEORGE, carrying the lamb, GABRIEL mar towards MRS HURST’s, a man with a mission. Middle-aged, wry and weather-worn, MRS HURST joins her ni in clearing brambles from the cottage garden. Tough work, BATHSHEBA scratched and muddy. MRS HURST stretches out her back and notices GABRIEL approaching.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HURST
dialogues.text: Goodness. Mr Oak.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: What does he want? INT. KITCHEN, MRS HURST’S COTTAGE - DAY 15 BATHSHEBA washes the mud from her hands, wipes it from he face, checks her reflection in the small mirror. It will to do. INT. PARLOUR, MRS HURST’S COTTAGE -— CONTINUOUS 16 GABRIEL and MRS HURST sit in the parlour, a little awkwar BATHSHEBA enters, and he stands abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Miss Everdene. Bathsheba. I’ve brought you a lamb.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: (delighted) Thank you, Farmer Oak! Such a dear thing, that’s very sweet of you.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: He’s come too soon and won’t last the winter. I thought you’d like to rear it instead.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Thank you. That’s very kind. MRS HURST takes the lamb out with her.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HURST
dialogues.text: I’1ll make some tea. And she makes her exit. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: The lamb is not why I came.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 8

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Well...I wanted to ask, Miss Everdene, if you’d marry me. A long moment.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Oh - This is not the response he wanted -

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: I’ve never asked anyone before.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: No, I - And impulsively he stands.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Well. I’1l leave you now.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Mr Oak - (he turns, waits) There are things to consider.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Someone waiting for you?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: No, there’s no-one else but that doesn’t mean I’1l marry you.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Good day to you then. 17 EXT. MRS HURST’S COTTAGE - CONTINUOUS 17 BATHSHEBA follows him out.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Mr Oak, stop! I didn’t say I wouldn’t marry you either! (he doesn’t understand - which is it?) I really haven’t ever thought about it. I need time to consider.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 9

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: But I know I can make you happy. (she’s thrown by this) I have one hundred acres, two hundred sheep, When I pay off the money, the farm is ours. You could have a piano in a year or two. Flowers and birds. A frame for cucumbers. A baby perhaps, or two -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Please, Mr Oak, that’s too much -

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: - or more. And whenever you look up I’1l be there, and whenever I look up there’ll be you. BATHSHEBA takes this in, imagines it, and makes her decis

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Mr Oak, I do not want a husband. I'd hate to be some man’s property. I shouldn't mind being a bride at a wedding, if I could be one without getting a husband, but -

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: That’s just stupid talk. With as much calmness and compassion as she can muster;

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: You are better off than I, Mr Oak. I have an education and this dress and nothing more. You can do much, much better than me...

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Maybe that’s true. But you know that’s not the reason.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I’m too independent for you. (this sounds more plausible) If I ever were to marry, I’d need somebody to tame me, and you’d never be able to do it. You'd grow to despise me.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: (with quiet simplicity) I would not. (she takes this in. A moment, then -) Goodbye, Miss Everdene.  18 19 20

dialogues.speaker: 20A
dialogues.text: FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 10 And with that he turns and goes. For a moment she follows him, just a step or two. Then sh walks back to the cottage. One last look. GABRIEL walks away, no turning back. EXT. GABRIEL’S CARAVAN, NORCOMBE HILL - DAY 18 WINTER. Time passing. GABRIEL is herding sheep as light snow falls. Hard, physi work. As night comes on, he rests on the steps of the Shepherd' Hut, the site of BATHSHEBA’s rescue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another day. In his caravan, OLD GEORGE by his side, GABR sleeps on. The barking of YOUNG GEORGE wakes them both. Something is He sits, listens. The sound of sheep bells now. He is on his feet. To OLD GEORGE -—

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Stay here, old boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GABRIEL steps out of the caravan, pulling on his clothes. listens to the distant barking to find the direction, the runs off. A broken fence nearby - EXT. GABRIEL’S CARAVAN, NORCOMBE HILL - DAWN 20A He walks through trees, losing track of the barking for a moment. Coming out of the trees and forest, he crests the hill in search of the flock. But they have gone. Disappeared. Silence. Then barking, the sound of the bells, further off this ti He runs —  21 22 23 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 11

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A natural basin leads up to cliffs and, beyond that, the The precipice is fenced off, but it is towards this cliff edge that the flock have been harried by YOUNG GEORGE. GABRIEL stumbles across the darkened hillside after them. ---but it’s too late. The young, impetuous dog is barking snapping at a single remaining sheep, forcing it through gap in the broken fence and into the darkness beyond. The sheep has gone. YOUNG GEORGE runs to his master, desperate for approval. GABRIEL is numb. With a terrible sense of foreboding, he walks towards the gap in the hedge, knowing already what he'll find. GABRIEL’s POV. A glimpse of white below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the bottom of the limestone cliff, the corpses of the flock. Two hundred sheep, all dead. The sun is up, the water lapping at the corpses. GABRIEL stands exhausted, numb. All of his hopes, his ambitions, rewards of twenty years hard work, all dead. At his side, YOUNG GEORGE licks his hand, awaiting his reward for a jo well done. He kneels next to YOUNG GEORGE, places his forehead again the dog’s and speaks to him quietly.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Least we didn’t marry, eh Georgie? Then he quickly stands and, without malice but with an aw resignation, he raises his gun. A shot rings out. INT. GABRIEL’S COTTAGE - DAY 23 Keys and cashbox handed to two GENTLEMAN FARMERS.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST FARMER
dialogues.text: Good luck to you, Mr Oak.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND FARMER
dialogues.text: And our sympathies.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST FARMER
dialogues.text: Where are you heading? (no reply) We take no pleasure in this.  24 25 26 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 12 GABRIEL ignores them and goes instead to OLD GEORGE.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Sorry, old boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another day. GABRIEL walks on, everything he owns now in pack on his back. Now snow falls. The road across Egdon Heath has disappear Desperate for shelter, he sees a barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GABRIEL wraps himself in his blanket and tries to sleep, breath hanging in the frozen air. There’s a hole in the roof. GABRIEL looks to the skies, thinks of BATHSHEBA - EXT. MRS HURST’S FARM - DAY 26

dialogues.speaker: MRS HURST
dialogues.text: Bathsheba! A shout. BATHSHEBA, working in the fields, stands. MRS HU runs towards her, waving something in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: What is it? A letter. She hands it to BATHSHEBA, breathless. Gasping air -

dialogues.speaker: MRS HURST
dialogues.text: Oh my love, it’s your poor Uncle's will.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: What does it say? What’s happened? Breathless, MRS HURST indicates.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HURST
dialogues.text: Read it! Read! BATHSHEBA does so - BATHSHEBA puts her hand to her mouth. Then she embraces h AUNT.  27 28 29 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 13 EXT. MRS HURST’S COTTAGE - DAY 27 The cart is loaded with suitcases and furniture. In her c dress once more, BATHSHEBA says farewell - - then clambers aboard, and finds a place amongst the precarious load. The cart trundles off, BATHSHEBA turning and waving goodb Excitement, anticipation. On her lap, the lamb. GABRIEL’s gift. The blare of a trumpet and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on SERGEANT FRANCIS TROY of the 11th DRAGOON GUARDS Fine-boned, a neatly-trimmed moustache on a finely struct face. The DRAGOONS are a splendid sight, a blaze of brass and scarlet on a January day. They ride towards the market town of CASTERBRIDGE EXT. TOWN SQUARE, CASTERBRIDGE -— DAY 29 The GUARDS are holding an opportunistic recruiting drive. TROY and the other troops stand at ease SERGEANT DOGGETT, attempts to muster new recruits.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT DOGGETT
dialogues.text: So who'll join us, lads? Which of you fine boys’1l put on the scarlet uniform and proudly serve his Queen and Country?... In amongst the crowd, a YOUNG WOMAN. She’s in her best dr but painfully under-dressed for the cold weather. She’s a encumbered by a large, impractical carpet bag. Neverthele there’s a kind of elation about her, as if she’s embarkin some adventure. An escape. This is FANNY ROBBIN. She pushes through the crowd towards the front, finding herself next to GABRIEL OAK; gaunt now, exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY ROBBIN
dialogues.text: Frank! Over here! Frank, it’s Fanny! TROY gives her a quick, fond glance, then fixes his eyes forward again.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: (to GABRIEL) My sweetheart. Over there.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 14

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT DOGGETT
dialogues.text: You, sir... (he has spotted GABRIEL) .---next to the pretty lady! (FANNY ROBBIN blushes) There’s a good strong figure of a man. Always room in the ranks for gentlemen of your calibre. Come join us, sir! A moment of hesitation.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Go on. You’d make a fine soldier. But GABRIEL shakes his head and shrinks back into the cro walking away as DOGGETT continues.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT DOGGETT
dialogues.text: Or that gentleman there, you look like a patriot. Come on lad, don’t be shy, step forward... GABRIEL takes one more look over his shoulder, then heads his way. But FANNY has followed him -

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: You might try Weatherbury! (GABRIEL turns) If you're looking for work, try Weatherbury. There’s a farm there needs all the help it can get.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Thank you. I’1l do that. (a moment. He notices her carpet-bag, her thin clothes) You should have a cloak, cold night like this.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: (with forced pride) Oh, no, Francis’ll take care of me. He’s a sergeant. We’re going to be married soon you see.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: But tonight, you have lodgings?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: No. Not tonight. Not yet. GABRIEL reaches into his pocket and offers her a coin.  30 31 32 33 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 15

dialogues.speaker: FANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am taken care of. (Pride vs. Necessity. GABRIEL persists.) But if you’re sure can spare it... (and she takes it) I‘ll repay you. I'll send it to Weatherbury. But please, don’t tell anyone there you saw me. I’ve run away you see. Let it be our secret. GABRIEL nods assent and she hurries off, carrying all her possessions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GABRIEL walks on towards Weatherbury now. Exhausted, it’s time to rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A feeble camp fire. Scooping leaves into a pile, GABRIEL makes a mattress of sorts in the woods. Exhausted from th day's humiliations, he pulls his blanket up and tries to sleep. The NOISES of the wood at night. And then a new noise. SH of alarm. GABRIEL sits. Through the trees, a red glow like the end cigar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half a mile away a fire is clearly visible, blazing out o control. Human shouts, the panic of cattle and horses. From the edge of the woods, GABRIEL watches impassively. of his business. Nothing to do with him. Then a decision. He heads off towards the flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hayrick in flames, burning with startling speed and intensity. The farmyard is in chaos; livestock crying in panic as me run uselessly back and forth in the orange light. At pres it’s the only one on fire, but a number of ricks stand cl and burning straw tumbles through the air, across to the great BARN that holds the crop.  34 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 16 A rag-tag group of farmhands - JOSEPH, JACOB, BILLY, LABA CAINY and JAN - all hurl water uselessly onto the flames. GABRIEL arrives.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Who’s in charge here?

dialogues.speaker: LABAN TALL
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Who’s in charge? Where’s your farmer?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH POORGRASS
dialogues.text: Look - the barn! Sure enough, the fire has spread to the roof of the barn, where all the crop is kept.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: This rick is lost. It’s the barn you need to save. D’you understand? They stare uselessly at the stranger.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ladder?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH POORGRASS
dialogues.text: It was on the rick. GABRIEL thinks for a moment. He takes the scarf from JOSE neck and wraps it around his face, making a make-shift ma Then he grabs a bucket of water, pours it over his head, strides towards the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A haywain has ignited, burning furiously down one side, t side nearest the barn.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Get it away! Now! And he leads the men in pulling the flaming cart away fro the precious barn. But it’s too late! The barn roof is starting to burn. They do so, but the cart itself is in flames now. GABRIEL steadies himself and looks across to the barn roof.  35 36 37 38 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 17

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GABRIEL runs inside, through smoke and the crop, searchin for a way to the roof. The whole building is a tinderbox, he clambers to the highest level despite the flames above him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now he appears on the roof (through a hatch? via a ladder? TO BE DISCUSSED) and begins smothering the burnin thatch as the MEN watch from below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fire is extinguished. Thick smoke hangs in the air, a battlefield after the fighting. GABRIEL, blackened and exhausted, is washing the soot from his face. He gathers possessions, ready to move on, when a maid approaches. Th is LIDDY -

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The farmer’s here.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: About time too. Where’s he been?

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: She'd like to thank you. GABRIEL stops still. Stands straight. A FIGURE approaches, her face covered against the smoke. WOMAN. She slows. Stops. She uncovers her face -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: No. It can’t be. GABRIEL smiles. And BATHSHEBA EVERDENE, owner of Weatherb Farm smiles back at him.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr Oak, is that really you?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Do you happen to want a shepherd, ma’ am?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the WORKERS clear away the fire damage, BATHSHEBA and walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 18

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I owe you an immense debt, Mr Oak. If I’d lost the barn, I’d have lost my farm.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Your farm?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: It's my inheritance - And they turn a corner, REVEALING the main house, a littl run-down perhaps, but still fine and imposing. BATHSHEBA (CONT’D) I loved it here as a little girl. When my uncle passed away, he left it to me. Of course it’s a little ragged now but this was once the finest farm for miles. I intend to make it so again. (she glances at Gabriel) Perhaps you find the idea preposterous too, Mr Oak?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: I no longer have that luxury.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I’m truly sorry to hear of your great loss, Mr Oak, but if this reversal of fortunes causes you any embarrassment... (GABRIEL is silent) ) I think it best if you address me as ‘ma’am’ or ‘Miss Everdene’. In turn I will address you as Mr Oak.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: I understand. Ma’am. An awkward smile, and she goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATHSHEBA sits at a great oak table, a cash box in front her. A noise from the doorway - LIDDY, BATHSHEBA’s maid, frien and confidante.  39 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 19 Fiercely protective of her mistress and, despite being th daughter of BILLY SMALLBURY, fiercely proud of her status

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Miss, the philistines are upon us! The MEN loiter in the doorway, waiting to be paid.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Send them in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little later. Paid or waiting to be paid are - JAN COGGAN - strong, capable, reliable, a companionable bachelor. LABAN TALL. Handsome, conceited, suspicious of GABRIEL’s charm. JOSEPH POORGRASS is weak, physically inept, painfully shy especially around BATHSHEBA. JACOB SMALLBURY, LIDDY’s grandfather, is the self-appoint elder statesman, given to wise pronouncements, alcohol an laziness. BILLY SMALLBURY, his son, is reliable, slightly put-upon both father and daughter. CAINY BALL is an awkward teenager, easily distracted, alw in the way. TEDDY COGGAN, JAN’s young brother, is the youngest, indul and spoiled by the others. TEMPERANCE and SOBERNESS MILLER are the opposite of what their names suggest; flirtatious, irreverent, ‘yielding’. MRS COGGAN is the housekeeper and cook, JAN’s mother, perpetually harassed and dusted in flour. SUSAN TALL is the ferocious, controlling wife of Laban, perpetually enraged at his boozing, his lack of social advancement. MARYANN MONEY is LIDDY’s side-kick, good-humoured, a drea easily perplexed.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 20 BATHSHEBA hands out the money to each in turn, LIDDY prou by her side. Next up is -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Joseph Poorgrass! Which one is Joseph Poorgrass? JOSPEH POORGRASS steps forward. LIDDY indicates ‘hat off’ BATHSHEBA (CONT’D) And what do you do, Joseph Poorgrass?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH POORGRASS
dialogues.text: I does general things and in Spring I shoot the rooks and help at pig- killing, Sir, I mean Ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Here’s seven and ninepence, and another ten shillings as I’m new.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH POORGRASS
dialogues.text: Thank you, Ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Now. Fanny Robbin? Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: JACOB SMALLBURY
dialogues.text: She has run away ma’am. With a soldier. GABRIEL picks up on this -

dialogues.speaker: PENNYWAYS
dialogues.text: Not a soldier, a sergeant! Sceptical laughter. BATHSHEBA is unamused.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Bailiff Pennyways, here is ten shillings and a further ten. This ends our association. You are dismissed.

dialogues.speaker: PENNYWAYS
dialogues.text: Beg pardon, ma’am?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: When my uncle was alive, this was a fine, productive farm. Since his death it has fallen into ruin - PENNYWAYS leans into BATHSHEBA, his face full of menace. GABRIEL stands, at the ready.

dialogues.speaker: PENNYWAYS
dialogues.text: Now see here, Miss -  40 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 21

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: - a fire threatens to destroy the barn and you’re nowhere to be found. I have no use for men like you, Mr Pennyways. You are dismissed. She holds her nerve. PENNYWAYS’s bluff is called. A momen he scans the room for support that will not come. Address the others -

dialogues.speaker: PENNYWAYS
dialogues.text: I'd get out while you can if I was you! And he leaves. If BATHSHEBA is shaken, she hides it well. Settling herself.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Now. You’ve met Mr Oak, our new shepherd. You understand your duties, Mr Oak?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: If I don’t, I'll ask you. Ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: (she stands to address the room) From now on you have a mistress, not a master. I don’t yet know my talents in farming, but I shall do my best. If you suppose, because I’m a woman, that I don’t know bad from good, right from wrong, then leave. But to those who choose to stay, I promise you this. I shall be up before you are awake, I shall be in the fields before you are up. It is my intention to astonish you all. Now - back to work, please. She stands and leaves the room. The WORKERS look on, some impressed, some sceptical, some duly astonished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the evening falls, FANNY walks through the mud of a riverside path in barely adequate shoes towards MELCHESTE BARRACKS. She still carries her carpet-bag, still on the move. It’s a barren, bleak landscape, and some of the hope, som the certainty has gone from FANNY’s adventure.  41 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 22 EXT. MELCHESTER BARRACKS — DUSK 41 A river. A wall, high and blank, with shuttered windows. FANNY counts the windows -

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: One, two, three, four... She picks up a handful of earth, throws it. The small win opens, and TROY appears.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Who’s there?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Is it Sergeant Frank Troy?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Frank, don’t you know me? Fanny Robbin!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Fanny!

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: How did you get here?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: You said I was to come.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Well...I said that you might. You’re too late!

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: You can’t come out and see me?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: No no, the barrack gates are closed and I have no leave. I'll find you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Tomorrow! Oh, Frank. Then I won’t see you till then?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Do you have a place to stay?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Yes. No. I’1l find somewhere. When will it be?  42 43 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 23

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: What you promised...Don’t make me say it. You say it first!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: You say it.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: When will we get married?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Soon —

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Have you asked permission?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: If I said I’1l marry you, I will.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Oh, I love you Francis Troy!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Shhhh! Tomorrow. He closes the window but FANNY lingers, full of hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Market Day. The building is at the very heart of the town imposing, high-domed and noisy, a sort of stock-exchange grain. Outside, BATHSHEBA and LIDDY hoist hefty bags of grain samples from her carriage and heads towards the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, it’s a temple of commerce, and a strictly male preserve that echoes with bargaining, banter and deal-mak - until BATHSHEBA enters, LIDDY behind her.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: (a whisper) We have a perfect right to be here. All heads turn. They could not be more surprised if a sma elephant had entered the hall. A silence. Then the murmur gossip, disapproval, some admiration. Meanwhile, one WELL-DRESSED GENTLEMAN clears his throat.  44 45 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 24

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, shall we return to business? This man is BOLDWOOD, forties, self-contained, handsome i Roman way; dignified, the nearest Casterbridge has to aristocracy, and clearly a step above the tradesmen aroun him. Needless to say, BATHSHEBA notices him -— But indifferent, BOLDWOOD returns to business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little later. Still BATHSHEBA stands alone, looking for first customer as the MALE CROWD mills around her. LIDDY returns;

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Perhaps we should go, Miss. But a FARMER catches her eye. There’s nothing for it -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: It’s Farmer Stone, isn’t it? I’m Farmer Everdene’s niece. He talked about you with such admiration. A moment. And the FARMER approaches -—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now BATHSHEBA is surrounded by FARMERS. She is enjoyi herself now, as she pours the grain sample into FARMER STONE’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER STONE
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Five pounds a quarter.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER STONE
dialogues.text: Three pounds ten shillings.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: You paid my uncle five pounds. It’s the same grain, Mr Stone.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER STONE
dialogues.text: Three pounds ten. And now BOLDWOOD has approached.  46 47 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 25

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: How about you, sir? You’1ll pay me five pounds? He tips his hat and walks away. BATHSHEBA watches him.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER STONE
dialogues.text: Very well. Four pounds -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: - and ten shillings.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER STONE
dialogues.text: Four pounds five.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Perhaps I should move on...

dialogues.speaker: FARMER STONE
dialogues.text: Very well. Four and ten. A handshake, the audience enjoying the show, almost as mu as BATHSHEBA is enjoying the success. Her eyes seek out BOLDWOOD, but he is already on to more important matters. MUSIC UP: The wheezing of a church organ, the sound of th choir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATHSHEBA and LIDDY are in their Sunday best, taking thei seats in the congregation.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: It was as bad as being married. Eyes everywhere!

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Men! They do like to stare at us.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: There was only one man who had the good sense to pay no attention to me —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hymn. BOLDWOOD sings in a strong dignified baritone. Bu despite BATHSHEBA’s glances, he remains maddeningly indifferent. Elsewhere, GABRIEL sits in the gallery with the MALE WORK attracting admiring glances from the WOMEN opposite. He observes BATHSHEBA, observing BOLDWOOD.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 26

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Rich, handsome, it sends the local girls mad. The Taylor sisters worked at him for two years. Jane Perkins spent twenty pounds in new clothes and might as well have thrown it out the window. It’s said when he was young his sweetheart jilted him...

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: People always say that. Women don’t jilt men. Men jilt us.

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Did someone jilt you, miss? And there’s GABRIEL, talking with the other MEN.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Me? Certainly not. A man did ask to marry me once, some time ago.

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: And you wouldn't have him?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I thought he wasn’t good enough for me.

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: What a luxury, to have a choice. ‘Kiss my foot sir, my face is for mouths of consequence’.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: It wasn’t like that at all.

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Why? Did you love him? BATHSHEBA doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early February morning, and BATHSHEBA is the first in the fields as promised, a shotgun slung across her back, a pa of pheasants hanging by her side. BATHSHEBA watches and waits, and is about to fire when - She hears a noise behind her, and turns. MR BOLDWOOD is t on horseback. He rides on.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Mr Boldwood!  49 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 27

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Don’t shoot me, please.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I had no intention of shooting you. (nothing) It's Miss Everdene! Your neighbour. Farmer Everdene’s niece? I’m managing the farm alone now, perhaps you'd heard.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m sure you'll do very well. In the circumstances. (BATHSHEBA bridles) Well. As you say, we are neighbours. Good hunting, Miss Everdene. And that’s it. BATHSHEBA watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surrounded by books, papers, dusty boxes, BATHSHEBA and L are sorting through Farmer Everdene’s old belongings.

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Listen to this. ‘The Rose is red, The Violet blue, Carnations sweet...’

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: What are you doing, Liddy?

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: It’s a valentine. I was going to send it to Joseph Poorgrass, just to see the look of panic on his face. A gawdy, sentimental confection of paper and lace.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Poor boy. A little far-fetched, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Either him or Mr Oak -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: (abruptly) No. Certainly not Mr Oak.

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: I know! Let’s send it to high and mighty Mr Boldwood! Ignoring you like that..  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 28

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Or perhaps not.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: No, we must!

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: We mustn’t!

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Because he won’t see the humour -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I’m sure he will. Or perhaps he won't, perhaps it is too much.

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Perhaps it is. (But it’s too much fun to miss) Unless we toss for it. From the debris, she finds a book.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Open Boldwood, closed -

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Joseph Poorgrass.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Closed - Joseph, open - Boldwood.

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Are we ready?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Quickly, before I change my mind! And she tosses the book high into the air. It lands. Open  50 51 52 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 29 INT. DINING ROOM, BOLDWOOD’S MANSION - DAY 50 THE VALENTINE. It lies in its envelope on the large dinin table in Boldwood’s large, comfortable house. BOLDWOOD raises his tea to his lips, and glances casually the envelope. He turns it over. Facing him is the wax seal. Imprinted in the red wax the words - ‘Marry Me’ Carefully, he places the tea-cup down. He checks the addr yes, no mistake there. With forensic care, he takes a knife and carefully prises open the envelope so as not to break the seal, then pulls the card; the gaudy confection of lace and cupids. An entirely foreign object, he holds it with his finger tips He opens it, and a perfectly ordered world is knocked out shape. INT. ALL SAINT’S CHURCH, CASTERBRIDGE - DAY 51 A service is just ending and as the PARISHIONERS disperse TROY walks towards the PRIEST, splendid in full uniform, nerves concealed behind his swagger.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Sergeant Troy, for half-past eleven.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Yes, Sergeant Troy and -

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Miss Fanny Robbin. We’re getting married. INT. ALL SAINT’S CHURCH, CASTERBRIDGE - DAY 52 Later. TROY, stands erect at the altar, impassive. The so of a door behind him. He doesn’t turn, but smiles in anticipation of the sight of his bride... But it’s only SERGEANT DOGGETT, his best man.

dialogues.speaker: DOGGETT
dialogues.text: Sorry I’m late, old boy. Not long now. A few PARISHIONERS have remained to spectate.  53 54 55 56 57 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 30

dialogues.speaker: PARISHIONER ONE
dialogues.text: (whispers) Where is she? TROY doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And sure enough, here comes FANNY ROBBIN hurrying along. looks beautiful, a simple bunch of flowers grasped in her hand. INT. ALL SAINT’S CHURCH, CASTERBRIDGE - DAY 54 The PRIEST has now taken a seat. TROY’s composure remains intact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALL SOUL’s CHURCH is up ahead. FANNY pauses for a moment, takes a deep breath, composes herself, suppresses her joy And enters. A GROOM stands at the altar. A BRIDE too. Consternation a the small CONGREGATION turn and see FANNY in her wedding dress. Confusion. INT. ALL SAINT’S CHURCH, CASTERBRIDGE - DAY 56 Meanwhile TROY still waits. Discomfort now. The OLD LADIE whispering. There is some laughter, but TROY’s features remain fixed. The church bells start to chime. DOGGETT places his hand TROY’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DOGGETT
dialogues.text: Don’t think she’s coming, old boy. A moment. Then with a snap of his heels TROY turns and marches back down the aisle with as much dignity as he ca muster. As he passes, the OLD LADIES smile sympathetically. ‘Poor lamb!’ Enraging! Humiliating. EXT. ALL SAINT’S CHURCH, CASTERBRIDGE - DAY 57 FANNY hurtles across the square just in time to see a ste TROY marching away from the church.  58 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 31

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Frank! Oh, Frank! Wait! TROY doesn’t break stride as FANNY tries to make light of

dialogues.speaker: FANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There's been a mistake! I thought you told me All Soul’s not All Saint’s! I went to the wrong church! I thought you’d jilted me, Frank! (No smile) I don’t blame you, but I’m sure you did say...or perhaps it was my mistake after all. Still, we’re here now! Smile, Frank, please? (He doesn’t speak.) Tomorrow then! We’ll get married tomorrow, just the same? And TROY stops and turns on her. With barely concealed ra

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Do you think I’1l be humiliated a second time?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: It was a mistake, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: (striding on) It was.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: You will marry me though, won't you, Frank? You promised, and you know I love you. Don’t walk away. I have nowhere else to go. Tell me, I beg you, when? When? People are watching now, she’s struggling to maintain her pride despite growing panic. She takes TROY’s arm, he sha her off. There’s a final look from TROY before he turns and walks away, leaving FANNY, heartbroken, standing in the street her wedding dress. INT. DINING ROOM, BOLDWOOD’S MANSION - DAY 58 ‘Marry Me’. The words in red wax on the envelope, which n sits on BOLDWOOD’s mantelpiece. BOLDWOOD takes his breakfast, as before, but now his eye returns to the envelope. The BUTLER arrives, bearing the post. BOLDWOOD sorts thro it eagerly, stops -  59 60 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 32 He crosses to the window. In the Everdene fields beyond, GABRIEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GABRIEL is stacking logs with the help of little TEDDY COGGAN. BOLDWOOD strides purposefully across fields towar him.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Mr Oak! A little LATER. BOLDWOOD now helping GABRIEL with his wor BOLDWOOD (CONT’D) A letter came to me by mistake. ‘The new shepherd, Weatherbury’ I can only assume it’s for you. GABRIEL opens the letter. The COIN, returned from Fanny a promised. A simple note. ‘Thank You For Your Kindness’ BOLDWOOD, meanwhile, produces his pocket book, containing letter. With forced casualness -

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: On a separate matter, between ourselves, I wonder, do you know whose handwriting this is? (He shows him the envelope) It's just a foolish thing -

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: There was no name?

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: No, I believe that is where the fun lies. Do you recognise it? He does. And with recognition, he understands BATHSHEBA’s intentions too. Her perceived ambition. It all makes terr sense.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Miss Everdene’s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deaf to the noise around him, BOLDWOOD watches BATHSHEBA. For the first time he notices the curve of her neck, the colour of her lips, the shape of her ear. To FARMER STONE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 61 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 33

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Is Miss Everdene considered attractive?

dialogues.speaker: FARMER STONE
dialogues.text: (has he gone mad?) Very much indeed. FARMERS surround her, as she smiles, banters, negotiates a HANDSOME YOUNG MAN, all watched from BOLDWOOD’s P.O.V. Another new experience - jealousy. Suddenly she looks across, and catches his eye. Hurriedly looks away. This is all new. For the first time in his life, his hear has begun to move within him. INT. BOLDWOOD’S MANSION - NIGHT 60A And so he sits. Insomniac. All peace of mind lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: End of May and the time comes for sheep-washing. To this a series of fences have been set up, obliging the sheep t enter a deep stonework pool. Up to their chests in chill water, stand GABRIEL and his assistant shepherd JAN. They must hold the panicked sheep under water then hoist them on to dry land. BATHSHEBA and LIDDY arrive.

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Careful you don’t get wet, Mr Oak!

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Perhaps you’d care to lend a hand? The MEN laugh.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: You don’t think I could? Very well. And BATHSHEBA strides towards the water and, without hesitation, steps right in. She is able and strong, smiling at the applause of the laughter of the others then getting on with the work. For one moment, in the muddy water, we see the shapes of BATHSHEBA and GABRIEL’s hands meeting for a moment.  62 63 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 34 EXT. YARD -— DAY 62 BOLDWOOD, in his Sunday best, hears the shouts and splash of the sheep-dipping, and approaches. Then stops. The most extraordinary sight. BATHSHEBA up to her waist i the water, manoeuvring the sheep through the water. LIDDY approaches him quickly and he speaks to her for a moment, passing on a message.

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Mister Boldwood wondered if he might have a word.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Mr Boldwood, of course, perhaps later? I’1l need to - BOLDWOOD nods and leaves. BATHSHEBA hauls herself out of water. The MEN exchange meaningful glances.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Back to work. They do so. But GABRIEL can’t help but watch BATHSHEBA. EXT/INT. TERRACE/GREAT HALL, BOLDWOOD’S MANSION - DAY 63 The house is beautiful. BATHSHEBA and BOLDWOOD stand on t terrace, somewhat self-conscious.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: One-thousand acres, a mix of arable and livestock. An orchard. A glasshouse. I have some interesting pigs. (BATHSHEBA laughs. BOLDWOOD too) Some other time perhaps. BATHSHEBA and BOLDWOOD walk through the fine hall, BOLDWO watching her, noting how she fits in here. This seems rig

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: You have a very beautiful house. (no reply from BOLDWOOD) Mr Boldwood?

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Forgive me, perhaps I should...I’1l speak plainly. I have felt lately, more and more, that my present way of living is bad, in every respect bad. But we all change, and my change in this matter came with seeing you.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 35 And BATHSHEBA knows what must come next.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Miss Everdene, I want, very much, more than anything, to have you as my wife. (grasping her hand - ) Miss Everdene - marry me!

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I feel, Mr Boldwood, though I respect you very much, I do not feel - what would justify me to - in accepting your offer. BOLDWOOD looks as if he has been struck.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: I see. I have known disappointments in the past, and I wouldn’t have asked in this instance if I hadn’t been led to believe - (he fumbles in his pocket, the ENVELOPE) Unless...unless I’m mistaken -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: The valentine. No, you’re not mistaken, but I should never have sent it. Forgive me, it was thoughtless to disturb your peace of mind -

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: ‘Thoughtless’?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Impetuous, frivolous -

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: So - you meant it as a joke?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: No! Not a joke, not exactly -

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Then a premonition perhaps? Of future feelings?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I haven't fallen in love with you. Certainly I may say that. I like and respect you very much but you’re too...dignified for me.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 36

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Too dignified? I see. Perhaps you think I’m too old, but I’11 take more care of you than anyone your own age -—

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: - I’m sure you would -

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: I‘1ll protect you, and care for you, you shall have no worries, your farm shall be looked after by a man, you shall never have to so much as look out of doors at harvest time. (BATHSHEBA shakes her head) You shall have dresses, a gig, a piano - (- and smiles, despite herself) I amuse you?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: No, it’s only...I have my own piano, and my own farm and I have no need for a husband. (BOLDWOOD doesn’t know what to say) I think I'd like to return home. My hat, please...

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Yes, yes of course. I’ll...1I’1l1 get someone to drive you. Your hat. But he’s in something of a daze, knocked sideways by this disappointment. BATHSHEBA sees this, and takes pity.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Mr Boldwood. I have made you miserable. It was very wicked of me And in her apology he sees his chance.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Will you reconsider? She takes him in. Handsome, dignified. Would it be so bad

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I hope for a change of heart?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Don’t hope. Let me think.  64 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 37

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, I'll give you time. (He smiles, gives her the hat) I will wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GABRIEL works alone by lamplight, sharpening blades on a pedal-driven grindstone in anticipation of the impending shearing. Sparks illuminate GABRIEL’s face.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: You’re working late, Mr Oak.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: We’ll need sharp blades for the shearing. His manner is subdued. There’s something on his mind. So

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Will you teach me? GABRIEL gives up his seat at the grindstone. BATHSHEBA si down, and GABRIEL sets the wheel in motion.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Here — (he sits behind, arms wrapped around her) Incline the edge so. That’s right. Like that. His hands cover hers. The wheel spins. Too casually -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I wanted to ask, did the men say anything today, about Mr Boldwood?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Yes they did.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: What did they say?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: That you’d be married before the end of the year.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I see. Well I'd like you to contradict it, to the men. And any warmth there might have been instantly disappears The wheel spins, then GABRIEL speaks -—  A beat. FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 38

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Well, Bathsheba -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: ‘Miss Everdene’ please -

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: - if Mr Boldwood did really speak of marriage then I’m not going to tell stories just to please you.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I said that I wanted you just to mention that it was not true that I was going to marry him.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: I can say that if you wish. I could also give an opinion of what you've done.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I dare say, but I do not want your opinion, Mr Oak!

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: I suppose not.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Well, what is your opinion?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: That you are greatly to blame for playing pranks on a man like Mr Boldwood. Your actions were unworthy of you.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Unworthy! May I ask where my unworthiness lies? In rejecting you perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: I’ve long given up thinking of that.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Or wishing it?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Or wishing it either. (Does he mean it? Has he moved on? This blow hits too. With great dignity) But I will say this; (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 39

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Leading on a man you don’t care for is beneath you. And with this parting shot he turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I cannot allow an employee to criticise my private conduct. You will please leave the farm at the end of the week!

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: (calmly) I'd prefer to go at once.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Then go! I never want to see your face again! A long moment.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Very well ‘Miss Everdene’. I’1l go first thing tomorrow. He walks away with great dignity, and BATHSHEBA can only watch him go. 65 EXT. GABRIEL’S COTTAGE - DAY 65 His possessions on his back, GABRIEL closes the door of h small, comfortable cottage, and sets off once again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bathsheba gallops up, Jan and Joseph running alongside. Scattered across the field the sheep lie on their side, t stomachs swollen, Jacob and Billy examining them.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: What is wrong with them?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH POORGRASS
dialogues.text: They broke fence and got into a field of young clover. Makes their stomachs swell. Come see. They approach one particular sheep, breathing fast, foam its mouth.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: How did this happen? Who let them break fence? (the men look at the ground) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 40

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And why didn’t you tell me sooner? (BATHSHEBA kneels.) Poor thing. What do we do now?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH POORGRASS
dialogues.text: Nothing. The whole flock is blasted.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Blasted? You mean they’re all going to die?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY SMALLBURY
dialogues.text: Most probably.

dialogues.speaker: JAN COGGAN
dialogues.text: (with a sheep) Another one gone here.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: But there must be something we can do!

dialogues.speaker: JACOB SMALLBURY
dialogues.text: (the elder, sagely) Only one way of saving them.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: What is it? Tell me, quickly!

dialogues.speaker: JACOB SMALLBURY
dialogues.text: They must be pierced in their side with a tool made on purpose. A hollow pipe, with a pricker inside.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Well can you do it? Eventually -

dialogues.speaker: JACOB SMALLBURY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Can I?

dialogues.speaker: JACOB SMALLBURY
dialogues.text: Good lord, no. One inch to the right or left and you kill the ewe for sure. Not even a shepherd can do it as a rule.  67 68 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 4l

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Then who? Tell me! (They look at the floor-) No. Oh no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GABRIEL is well on his way to Casterbridge with his possessions on his back. Healthier than when we first saw him, but on the road again. A shout comes across the fields.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH POORGRASS
dialogues.text: Gabriel! Gabriel Oak! Wait! He turns, curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATHSHEBA stooped over another dying sheep. Elsewhere -

dialogues.speaker: JAN COGGAN
dialogues.text: Lost another one, ma’am Breathless, JOSEPH POORGRASS rides up.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Why are you alone? Did you find him?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH POORGRASS
dialogues.text: Yes miss...

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: So what did he say?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH POORGRASS
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) He said...

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Joseph, please... All are listening.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH POORGRASS
dialogues.text: He said you’re to come in person and request him civilly in a proper manner.  69 70 71 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 42

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Where does he get his airs! I’1l do no such thing!

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH POORGRASS
dialogues.text: He said you’d say that. He said to reply that ‘Beggars can’t be choosers’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GABRIEL waits patiently, a picture of nonchalance as a fi on horseback appears. BATHSHEBA. If he’s enjoying this, he tries not to let it show. The m ghost of a smile as he stands. BATHSHEBA dismounts. With some effort, she re-arranges he face, from vexed pride to forced humility.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Mr Oak. Gabriel? (a deep breath) Please don’t desert me, Gabriel. I need your help. A moment. Then he walks abruptly towards BATHSHEBA... --.and past her, taking the reins of the horse, mounting He's about to ride off. BATHSHEBA (CONT’D) Make room for me. GABRIEL smiles and holds out his hand to her -

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Hold on. He urges the horse into a gallop, BATHSHEBA holding on ti around his waist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - then across the fields. LIDDY, JAN COGGAN and the other see them approach. JAN smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JAN COGGAN
dialogues.text: You sly old dog...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GABRIEL kneels over a bloated sheep, reaches into his poc and produces a strange instrument.  72 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 43 A brass rod, with a needle concealed inside, a kind of ba syringe. Like a surgeon, he passes his hand over the shee flank.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Find the spot...just here, between the ribs... And with a sudden, skilled motion, he stabs the sheep. BATHSHEBA and the others recoil.

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Oh Lord!

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Looks worse than it is. Now- The lance pierces the skin, and when the needle is remove the air rushes audibly through the tube. Slowly the sheep visibly deflates, a living balloon. BATHSHEBA can’t help laugh. GABRIEL smiles and sets to work on his next patien

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATHSHEBA has the syringe now, and leans poised over a bloated sheep. The other WORKERS look on -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Here?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Fast and strong and she won't feel it. He takes her fingers, places them on a spot over the shee ribs. BATHSHEBA summons up her courage, raises the syring like a dagger -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Liddy! (she raises it again) Perhaps you should do it.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: And when I’m not here? BATHSHEBA stabs the sheep. The needle is removed, the she deflates. The crowd sighs in relief. BATHSHEBA laughs...  73 74 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 44

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now the sun is setting, and BATHSHEBA watches, admiri his skill and dedication as GABRIEL, lit by lamps, moves expertly from one sheep to the next.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Ridiculous animals. Always getting into trouble. And if GABRIEL remains his own misfortune, he doesn’t say anything. The last of the sheep is on its feet again. He crosses to BATHSHEBA, and they survey the scene. BATHSHEBA (CONT’D) Gabriel. Stay on with me? He smiles. And nothing more needs to be said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A celebratory meal. BATHSHEBA’s piano has been moved out the yard and decorated with flowers, and JAN COGGAN plays sings a tune. GABRIEL is dressed smartly, a man on the move at one end the table, BATHSHEBA at the other. As twilight falls and the music plays, BATHSHEBA surveys bucolic scene and allows herself a smile for her achievements. Her eyes meet GABRIEL’s in gratitude. JOSEPH POORGRASS, meanwhile, has conquered his nerves eno to sing a song, a truly awful dirge, literally MONOTONOUS

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH POORGRASS
dialogues.text: I sowed the seeds of love/It was all in the spring.... It’s all too much for LIDDY, who has the tablecloth stuff into her mouth to suppress laughter. JOSEPH POORGRASS (CONT’D) O the willow tree will twist... The fit of giggles is spreading along the table. BATHSHEB struggles with a straight face. Then she sees a new arriv MR BOLDWOOD.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: (premature applause) Thank you Joseph! That’s enough. (JOSEPH sits) Mr Boldwood! Will you join us? Where - (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 75 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 45

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (a place for him to sit) Gabriel, would you mind... A brief moment of awkwardness as the social order re- establishes itself. But -

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY/MARYANN/TEMPERANCE AND SOBERNESS
dialogues.text: There’s a space next to me, Gabriel!/Over here, Mr Oak!/Come and sit with us, Mr Oak! He joins LIDDY further down the table.

dialogues.speaker: JACOB SMALLBURY
dialogues.text: A song, ma’am? General approval at the notion.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Me? I couldn’t possibly! (LIDDY and GABRIEL share an ironic smile) I don’t know what to say! Very well. She sits at the piano and begins to play. The song is ‘Th Banks of Allan Water’ and, after a moment’s nervousness, sings it beautifully. GABRIEL watches her, then turns to look at BOLDWOOD, enthroned at the head of the table, the heir apparent. GABRIEL notes the devotion in his eyes. To everyone's surprise, he starts to sing too. A faltering baritone tha grows in confidence. The song becomes a duet then ends with LOUD APPLAUSE. GAB realises that this is a battle that he can never hope to He joins in the applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the exquisite evening, a lantern between them, BATHSHE and BOLDWOOD walk away from the party.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: I thought we were rather good.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: So did I! (They laugh. A beat.) I wanted to thank you for not approaching me again on...that subject.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: It has not been easy.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 46

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: And I’m grateful for your restraint, Mr Boldwood. I can't give you my answer tonight but by the end of the summer, in six weeks time, my mind will be clearer and you'll have my decision then.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: It’s enough. It’s more than I hoped for.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Was there...anything else? A moment. Will he kiss her? Her face is raised towards hi exquisite in the glow of the lamp. She smiles - granting permission. But -

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Do you wish me to accompany you back to the house? With disappointment, BATHSHEBA registers the hesitation.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: No, I like to walk around the farm myself each night, to make sure all is safe.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Then I’11 walk with you -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I’ve done it many times alone. Goodnight, Mr Boldwood. And she walks off, leaving BOLDWOOD hopeful, BATHSHEBA thoughtful.  76 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 47

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A narrow, overgrown footpath through a fir plantation. Th passage is barely wide enough for one and she’s disconcer to see another figure enter the corridor ahead of her. A MAN. A moment of fear and hesitation. She gathers her nerves, lowers the lantern and proceeds to walk. The male figure closer. A scarlet jacket, unbuttoned, an uncertain step. They are about to pass. Head down, she squeezes by and - - is immediately stopped in her tracks. Her dress has bec entangled with the spurs -

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Have I hurt you?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: No -

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: We are entangled. Let me - He turns on the lantern. She places the lantern on the ground, sending great shadows dancing in the trees. He takes it from her, and raises it so that their faces a illuminated. SERGEANT FRANK TROY. The sudden sight of all that silver and scarlet is like t blare of a trumpet. BATHSHEBA is taken aback. TROY too.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Good God! They kneel together simultaneously, then with the lantern shining onto their faces, they untangle the knot.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: We've got hitched together somehow.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Then it seems you’re my prisoner -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: You’re making it worse on purpose -  77 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 48

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Now why would I do that?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Let me do it myself-

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Why such a hurry? Husband waiting? (BATHSHEBA is silent) I have a knife here.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: No! Here, let me try- (He can’t look away.) Please don’t stare.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I can’t help myself.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: You’re drunk. I smell it on your breath.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I don’t think I’ve ever seen a woman as beautiful as you.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: How dare you!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Take it or leave it, it’s the truth. The knot comes undone suddenly, causing her to stumble backwards. He pulls her to her feet. A moment as they face each other, then she bustles off. T her back -

dialogues.speaker: TROY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: At least tell me your name! Where do you live? I want see you again! And he watches her as she disappears into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bright SUMMER’s day and the FARM WORKERS are making hay The MEN lead, scythes flashing in the sun. The WOMEN, wea tilt bonnets to protect them from the sun, follow on behi raking the cut hay into windrows - ranked piles left to d in the sun before binding into sheaths.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 49 LIDDY and BATHSHEBA join in the work.

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Miss, look - Amongst the dull yellow smocks, a bright white shirt; TRO with a scythe, energetically mowing ahead.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Who is he, Liddy?

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Sergeant Francis Troy. Mother was a French governess, father was a doctor. Or an Earl, depending on what you believe. Noble blood, full of promise, very sharp and trim. Well educated, good things expected of him, and he threw it all in to be a soldier. And a walking ruin to decent girls. (BATHSHEBA gives her a look. ) So they say.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: (tuts, strides off) Well I won’t have it.

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: What are you doing, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I’m going to tell him to leave! And she strides towards TROY. LIDDY watches, amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TROY watches her approach. The other workers too, stop an stare, GABRIEL amongst them.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Sergeant Troy, I must absolutely insist that you leave this very moment !

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I can’t, I have to work off my sin. He goes back to work.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Well...I wish you wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Why not?  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 50

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Because I’d rather not thank you.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: And I’d rather not leave. So I won't. And he returns to work. BATHSHEBA left staring at his bac GABRIEL lays down his scythe and is about to intervene.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: (To TROY, sternly-) Will you follow me, please? And she strides off through the tall grass. TROY puts dow his scythe, and follows, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Farmer Everdene, you're quite the local legend.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Please!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: What angers you exactly? What I said, or the way I said it?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Neither...both! I won’t allow strangers to be impudent, even in praise.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Even if it’s the truth? You must know. There must be some man who tells you that you’re beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Not to my face, not exactly -

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: But there must be someone, who kisses you and tells you -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I’ve never been kissed. (The admission surprises both of them. They stop.) Why couldn’t you have just passed by and said nothing?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Half the pleasure of a feeling lies in being able to express it. Do you forgive me.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 51

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I do not!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Because...the things you say.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I said you were beautiful and I'll say it again. The most beautiful face I ever saw.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: That’s simply not true -

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: But you’ve never seen yourself through a man’s eyes -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Of course not -

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: - you don’t know what it’s like.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: What is it like?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Like not being able to think, or hear, or look in any direction. Except one. BATHSHEBA glances to where the WORKERS and GABRIEL, are staring. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I hope you fight as well as you speak.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Better. Meet me tomorrow, eight o'clock and I’1l1 show you.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: You don’t want to?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Yes, but -  79 80 81 82 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 52

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Then you must.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I mustn’t. I can’t tell you why, but I mustn't...

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: But you could. Nobody would know.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Then I must bring Liddy...

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Now why would you want to do that?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Please. Go now.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Tomorrow night. Eight o’clock. The hollow in the ferns. He turns and walks casually away, leaving BATHSHEBA flush and breathless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATHSHEBA attempts to read. But her mind is elsewhere. Exasperated, she puts down the book. Glances at the clock Picks up the book. Should she go? And -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she goes, is she dressed right? She assesses herself i the mirror. She wears her finest summer dress, pulling th material against her body. She looks exquisite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now she’s hurrying through the meadow towards her rendezvous, flushed in anticipation -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An uncultivated tract of land forms a natural amphitheatr at the base of which stands a smudge of scarlet. TROY, waiting. BATHSHEBA watches him a moment, breathless. She should le immediately. But he sees her, and smiles.  83 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 53

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An exquisite evening, sultry and sensual. TROY is giving lesson, a fearsome looking sword glinting in his hand. The sword exercise is a series of lethal looking slashes thrusts, very precise. TROY narrates as he demonstrates.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Four right and left cuts, four right and left thrusts. (The sword hisses through the air. BATHSHEBA watches, entranced. ) Cut one is as sowing corn, two as if hedging. Three as if reaping, four as if threshing...Do you trust me?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: (He removes his jacket.) Now. You are my enemy, with this exception; I shall miss you every time by a hair’s breadth... (His hand on her waist, he positions her as if for a dance.) I give you my word as a soldier, I will not harm you. The sword is blunt, but you must not flinch.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I‘1l try not to.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: (He readies himself) Very well. Let’s begin. And suddenly the air is filled with the swash of the blad glinting in the sun’s low rays as TROY repeats the exerci the blade passing thrillingly close to BATHSHEBA’s body. And then the display is over. TROY is sweating and BATHSH too is exhilarated.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Is it over?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Yes. Except — And he raises the point of the sword once more to her che A flick of the wrist, and a lock of hair falls.  84 85 86 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 54

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: How did you...how could you cut my hair?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: This sword could skin you alive.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: You lied! You told me I was safe!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: And you were, entirely safe. I gave you my word. (He steps closer.) Now, I will take this - - the lock of dark hair lies on her breast. Instinctively BATHSHEBA turns her face up towards him, and he takes her face in his hands. Her first kiss has a startling passion, like nothing she ever experienced before. His hand, too, is between her le She gasps. And then, with a coolness that’s almost callous, he simpl walks away, leaving BATHSHEBA breathless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as night falls, she walks slowly home, transformed. T night is warm, it has a sensuality to it. Something has changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATHSHEBA dresses for her rendezvous. There is no hesitat this time. She stands...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and hurries through the courtyard towards her next rendezvous with TROY. When -

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Miss Everdene. (she stops - caught) Perhaps I could walk with you.  87 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 55

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATHSHEBA and GABRIEL walk side by side in silence in the warmth of the summer evening. But BATHSHEBA is on edge, k to get away.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I’m quite happy to walk by myself.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: I’11 walk with you. They walk a little further.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Still, perhaps I’1l say goodnight -

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: You should have nothing to do with him. He’s not good enough for you.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Why ever not? He’s perfectly honourable, perfectly decent-

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: That’s not what I believe.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Why, what have you heard? Tell me! (And he could. He knows. But he hesitates.) You see, it’s all rumours, prejudice, simply because he’s a soldier -

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: I like soldiers, but not this one. I believe him to have no conscience at all. Stay clear. Don’t listen to him, don’t believe him. Get rid of him.
