dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: And why should you care? A moment. They both know.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: I’m not such a fool as to imagine I might stand a chance now that you are so...above me. But -— (A deep breath; this is hard.) Mr Boldwood loves you. You would be safe in his hands.  88 89 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 56

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: You want me to be ‘safe’? A beat. It pains him to say it, but -

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. A long moment. BATHSHEBA is touched, but also surprised b her own reaction. She reaches for indignation instead.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Then I think it might be best for both of us if you leave this farm immediately. But GABRIEL starts to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: This is the second time you've pretended to dismiss me —-

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Pretended! -

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: What’s the use of it? Sometimes I'd be glad as a bird to leave this place, for don’t suppose I’m content to stay a nobody all my life. One day I will leave you, you can be sure of that. But for now I care for you too much to see you go to ruin. So if you don’t mind, I'll stay by your side. BATHSHEBA smiles, GABRIEL too. But now another a figure approaches. TROY. He stops and waits a little way off. One moment’s hesitation, and she walks towards TROY. Without looking back, GABRIEL walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next day. BATHSHEBA writes a letter, seals an envelope To Boldwood, Lower Farm, Weatherbury.’ No turning back now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Decisive, BATHSHEBA goes to her wardrobe and begins to pa  90 91 92 93 94 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 57

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hurls her bag into her fastest gig, heads off into th night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as the sun rises, the city of Bath appears in the distance. A weary BATHSHEBA urges the horse on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the appointed time and place, TROY waits. Through the crowds, he sees her; BATHSHEBA, breathless wi anticipation. She watches for a moment and approaches. They stand in the street, tantalisingly close.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I wasn’t sure if you’d be here. Frank...

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Of course. Beneath her cloak, she reaches out one hand. Just their fingertips entwine. INT. DINING ROOM, BOLDWOOD’S MANSION - DAY 93 BOLDWOOD sits alone at a large dining table, taking his solitary breakfast, reading his mail just as he had on Valentine’s Day. A LETTER. He recognises the handwriting now. A rattling sound. He notices that his hand is shaking. Carefully, he puts his tea-cup down. BOLDWOOD opens the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coach from Bath makes its lonely way towards Weatherb BOLDWOOD watches the coach approach, his hand tightening the silver-headed cane. The coach stops at the top of the lane that leads to the Everdene farm. A figure descends; TROY starts to walk towards the farm. BOLDWOOD falls into step behind, cane in hand.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 58

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the approach to BATHSHEBA’s house now.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Going to see her I suppose? TROY walks on without turning.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Should I know you?

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: My name is William Boldwood.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Never heard of you.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Nevertheless, I wish to have a conversation. I don’t wish to enter into questions of right or wrong, you wouldn’t understand. I’ma businessman, and I intend a business transaction with you.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: I was engaged to be married to Miss Everdene until you came along.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Not quite engaged...

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: You have heard of me then.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: She told me some foolish old man was in love with her. You, I presume.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: (he lets this go) Miss Everdene will never marry you. You're not even an officer. She’s playing with you, you’re too poor, too low-down. A nobody. (TROY laughs this off -)

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: What is your proposal?  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 59

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Marry the other girl. Leave Miss Everdene alone. I'll make it worth your while. But this is like a slap for TROY. He considers Boldwood, taking him seriously now.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Leave tonight and I'll give you fifty pounds. The girl shall have money too, and after the wedding I‘1l settle a certain amount of money on the both of you, paid annually. You can resign your commission, leave this place, start a new life. And leave us be. TROY considers the deal.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Fifty pounds you say?

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: I have the money here. And he produces the money.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: You seem very confident I’11 accept.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: I know what you’re worth. TROY lets this pass. He takes the money, weighs it in his hand, then opens the gate and heads towards BATHSHEBA’s house. BOLDWOOD follows on, alarmed -

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where are you going? You must go tonight, that’s the agreement -

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I can’t just leave without saying goodbye. It’ll break her heart. I’1l tell her I’m not good enough then go straight away. How’s that?

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: No word of me or our arrangement. And never see her again, you must swear...  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 60

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I give my solemn vow as a soldier, that I will... (Almost at the door, he suddenly stops.) But wait a moment....

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: There’s a problem.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Tell me!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: We’re already married. You see? TROY holds his hand up to BOLDWOOD’s face. A gold band on his finger. BOLDWOOD is broken.

dialogues.speaker: TROY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We married first thing this morning. Lovely service in Bath, very quiet, the two of us. Tonight’s our wedding night. So, you see, it seems I am good enough for her after all. BOLDWOOD lunges, but TROY intercepts the blow. BOLDWOOD’s hand goes to TROY’s throat.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: I’‘1l kill you, d’you hear me! I'11 break your wretched neck! But TROY swiftly turns the table, shrugging off BOLDWOOD’ grip and hurling him to the ground. Three sharp blows to face - swift and effective.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: (whispering in his ear) Best kill yourself, old man. Don’t you think? (pushing him to the ground) Now - pick up your money and go. You’re trespassing.  96 97 98 99 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 61

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TROY surveys his home for the first time. He fingers a porcelain figure, a book. He picks out notes on the piano pours a glass of wine. His hand is still shaking. This is all his property now. For all its comforts, sudde it seems bourgeois, dowdy, dull. A twinge of doubt. There he realises, the potential for this all to go horribly wr A noise, a voice from above. TROY walks towards the stair

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They make love for the first time. In contrast to the bra and swagger of their past encounters, there’s something tender, tentative about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATHSHEBA sleeps soundly in the tangled sheets. Sounds from the yard wake TROY. Wearing breeches and his scarlet jacket, he sits on the edge of the crumpled bed a lights a cheroot. From outside, the sound of hammering -—

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. YARD, BEDROOM, EVERDENE FARM
dialogues.text: GABRIEL, POORGRASS and JAN COGGAN are in the yard, well i the working day.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Good morning, comrades!

dialogues.speaker: JAN COGGAN
dialogues.text: Morning sir! (hissed to GABRIEL-) Answer the man!

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Fine old house. Needs a lick of paint, don’t you think? (nothing from the MEN) You, Sir - (- GABRIEL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What’s your name? For a while it seems as if he might not answer.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Oak.  100 101 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 62

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Can’t hear you!

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: My name is Gabriel Oak. INTERCUT. BATHSHEBA hears this.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: (to JAN) Can you hear him? Mr Oak, please learn to smile and answer when you’re spoken to. I'll be down in the fields some time this week, but until then we’re not to be disturbed. (meeting GABRIEL’s eye; ) Here, this - (he tosses them coins) - is to drink our health. JAN stoops eagerly to pick up the coins, but GABRIEL does move. A figure has appeared behind TROY. BATHSHEBA, wrapp in the sheet of the marital bed, momentarily catches GABRIEL’s eye. Nothing shameful in her decision, but stil concern for GABRIEL.

dialogues.speaker: TROY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who is this Mr Oak?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: He’s my right hand. TROY takes this in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The harvest begins, the ricks piled high with the fruits the year. Back-breaking work, sweaty, the kind of occasio BATHSHEBA would once have relished. But not now. From a carriage at the edge of the field the newly-marrie couple watch the workers, sheltered from the heat and humidity. TROY is now a Gentleman Farmer, ill-at-ease in civilian clothes. BATHSHEBA in her fashionable clothes is observer, no longer a participant. GABRIEL glances over at her, then returns to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dusty from the days labours, GABRIEL washes. Then notices great fat toad lumbers across the ground.  102 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 63 OAK kneels and watches its progress. The toad is looking shelter - a sure sign that a storm is coming. He looks to the skies too. The evening is clear, but dark clouds are already rolling in. Rooks caw, clouds of starl wheel confusedly around the sky. The night has a sinister aspect. There’s a sense of foreboding. The year’s harvest stands unprotected in the rick yard. The sound of MUSIC comes from the barn -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A band is playing and the barn is full of the WORKERS and their FAMILIES. Foliage and old chandeliers have been hun from the rafters, food and drink laid out Clapping, cheering and stomping as TROY and BATHSHEBA dan wonderful together, eyes locked. The dance ends to much applause, TROY and BATHSHEBA at its centre. TROY kisses h cheers, laughter.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Gentlemen! Silence! Friends, it is not only the Harvest Home that we're celebrating. This is also a wedding feast. A short while ago I had the happiness to lead to the altar this beautiful lady, your mistress, and only now have we been able to celebrate our happy news. So please, charge your glasses and raise them to - my wonderful wife, Mrs Bathsheba Troy! GABRIEL watches the applause, then approaches BATHSHEBA.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: (to BATHSHEBA) I have to tell you -

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: To me, please, Mr Oak.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: (to both of them) There’s going to be a storm. We need to protect the ricks or we’ll lose the harvest.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: And how do you know there’s going to be a storm?  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 64

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: (hesitates, then -) Certain signs. The animals.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: (laughing, teasing) The animals told you?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: I need five, six men for an hour, no more.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Frank, perhaps we ought to-

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Nonsense! Tonight’s our celebration. Oak, you have no glass in your hand - here. He pours a glass and offers it to GABRIEL.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: With all due respect, we need able- bodied working men, not drunks and fools...

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: It will not rain tonight. My wife forbids it! Now, if you’1l excuse me, Mr Oak. Gentlemen, one more thing. Even though I’m no longer Sergeant Troy! I remain a soldier in this one respect - (he beckons one of the MEN forward. He carries -) Bottles of the finest French brandy! A triple-strength dose to every man here! (Disquiet from BATHSHEBA, shouts and cheers from the men) And if any of you men show the white feather, then you can look elsewhere for a winter's work! And to cheers and applause, the bottles are passed round. BATHSHEBA, meanwhile, looks to GABRIEL, wanting to follow

dialogues.speaker: TROY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You wouldn’t leave our wedding party. Would you? He kisses her, and she does her best not to worry.  103 104 116 105 106 107 108 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 65

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But outside, dark clouds have indeed started to form in t evening sky. A distant flash of lightning. The harvest stands vulnerable and exposed. GABRIEL makes decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TROY is in amongst his MEN, laughing, joking, passing out brandy, trying to recreate the camaraderie of the barrack The WOMEN have largely gone - only SOBERNESS and TEMPERAN neither sober nor temperate, remain. The band strike up again, and TROY leads the singing of a bawdy song. Excluded, BATHSHEBA and all but a few of the WOMEN have no other choice but to turn and go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GABRIEL hauls the water-proofed tarpaulins into the yard. Attaching a rope to one corner, he hurls the other end ov the stacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mad dancing from the MEN, TROY the life and soul. A drink song now - something like The Barley Mow -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With great effort, GABRIEL hauls at the rope, dragging th tarpaulin over the top of the third stack. But the wind catches it, filling it like the sail of a ship. The storm is overhead now. No rain yet, just startling bl skeletons of crackling light. GABRIEL takes a long metal with a chain attached - imagine a giant needle and thread and jams it into the highest point of the rick. This he h will act as a lightning conductor. But there’s still so much to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From her bedroom, BATHSHEBA looks out of the window towar the rick yard. A flash of lightning. GABRIEL silhouetted against the sky as he begins the work of roughly thatchin the remaining stacks. She makes a decision. Hurriedly, excitedly, she removes h jewellery, her party shoes. The old BATHSHEBA, back again  109 110 111 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 66

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GABRIEL works on. BATHSHEBA walks towards him, lamp in ha in working clothes now.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: What can I do?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: It’s too dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: If it’s too dangerous for me, then it’s too dangerous for you. (GABRIEL hesitates) Just tell me what to do. A rumble of thunder; not much time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MEN are visibly staggering now. JOSEPH POORGRASS, sli and not used to drinking, is laughing hysterically. Young CAINY BALL, too young to drink, can barely stand. Meanwhi LABAN TALL has picked a fight with another man, and a mes brawl is starting. TROY, the Master of Revels, watches over them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perched on ladders on top of the rick, BATHSHEBA and GABR work together, hammering sheaves in to place to shelter t crop. Thunder rolls, lightning crackling but -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Still no rain.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: It'll come. A flash of lightning, the thunder following immediately.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Frightened?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Why, are you? As if in rebuke there’s a terrible crack. Lightning forks down from the black sky, and strikes the conductor. Then the terrible peal of thunder. BATHSHEBA, startled, stumbles and falls. GABRIEL grabs her arm and holds her. moment of relieved laughter -  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 67 And then the RAIN starts. An extraordinary downpour. BATHSHEBA (CONT’D) Gabriel, if I were to die - and I may die soon, and I’d hate you to think badly of me - (GABRIEL goes to protest) Please, let me explain. I didn’t intend to marry him. I had every intention of ending it, just as you’d advised. But he told me about another woman, a great beauty that he'd loved before and so, somewhere between jealousy and distraction..I married him. Please understand. (GABRIEL goes to speak) No opinions. I only wanted you to know. GABRIEL smiles. A moment of extreme closeness between the For a moment, they might almost kiss. But to what possibl end?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Go to bed, I can finish the rest without you. Let me help you - He helps her down the ladder. She holds him back.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Gabriel. Thank you. A look of immense gratitude and affection. GABRIEL accept it, and understands, and returns to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early morning. The work is completed and GABRIEL, exhaust climbs down from the last rick. But someone is watching. distance, MR BOLDWOOD.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Sir? (BOLDWOOD turns, walks smartly away. GABRIEL follows ) Mr Boldwood, sir -

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: I wanted to ensure your mistress’ crops were safe -

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL BOLDWOOD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait a moment, sir - Good work, Gabriel, she’s lucky to have you - He turns. Haunted, strained, pale, soaked to the skin.

dialogues.speaker: 112B
dialogues.text: FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 68

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: You seem unwell. You should go home.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, I will. (he hesitates) Oak, you know that things have not gone well with me lately. I was going to get a little settled in life, but it was not to be. I daresay I am something of a...joke about the parish, but I do want to make it clear that there was no jilting on her part. We were never engaged. No matter what people say, she promised me nothing. And yet, Gabriel, I feel the most terrible grief. (He turns to GABRIEL. With an awful false bonhomie ) Still! No woman ever had power over me for any length of time. Not a word to her. We understand each other, yes? And poor, mad BOLDWOOD walks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dreary day in AUTUMN. TROY stands alone in shirtsleeves broom handle clutched like a sword. He carries out the sw exercise, as before, the chickens pecking around him. But there’s something diminished, pathetic about the man in h civilian clothes. This private display is watched by BATHSHEBA, with concer and sadness as he completes the exercise then, in a mad f of rage, hurls the broom handle against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FIST connects with a man’s head. Blood and sweat. Marke day at the Corn Exchange has bought a BOXING MATCH to the town, and in a corner of the square a CROWD has gathered watch PATTERSON Vs. SULLIVAN. The fight has brought with it BEGGARS, GYPSIES, DRUNKS, GAMBLERS, SOLDIERS on furlough. And among them is TROY, smoking a cheroot, aloof, indifferent. A blow lands. SULLIVAN crashes to the ground. TROY scowls and stabs out his cheroot. His money is hande over to the BOOKIES. And TROY stalks off -  112c

dialogues.speaker: 112E
dialogues.text: FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 69

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and becomes aware of a BEGGAR WOMAN following close beh

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: No money, I’m afraid. All gone. He turns. And freezes. The BEGGAR-WOMAN, hunched, barely to stand, clutching a familiar, battered carpet bag. She's barely recognisable as FANNY ROBBIN. TROY is stunne

dialogues.speaker: TROY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fanny.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Hello, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? I thought you were at your mother’s, I thought you were safe. (taking her hands) You’re so pale. You’re shaking.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: I walked here. I’m very tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATHSHEBA has finished her business, and wants to return home. The carriage is empty. Where’s TROY? Impatient, she scans the street. The next BOXING MATCH has begun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TROY sees BATHSHEBA searching for him, getting closer

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: My wife mustn’t know - And there it is; ‘wife’.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Your wife. (she follows his look) Mrs Troy is very beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: No more than you. Fanny - (Searching his pockets-) Six-pence. It’s all I have left. Take it -  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 70

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From BATHSHEBA’S p.o.v., she sees her husband talking to WOMAN, sees the lingering touch of hands, the exchange of money. An unmistakable intimacy, a terrible blow. She quickens her pace -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to TROY and FANNY. BATHSHEBA is nearly there - he sp quickly, desperately...

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I’ve made a terrible mistake, Fanny, but I will make amends. I swear on my life, I'll find a way to be with you.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: You’ve sworn before, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: But this time, this time... (FANNY smiles sceptically) Go to Budmouth, stay at the Union -

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: The workhouse, Frank? —

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: (quickly) Tonight, just tonight, one night, then meet me tomorrow at ten at the bridge. I will bring you all the money I have, I’1l find a place for you. You’11 want for nothing and I promise you, I will make amends. (-heading to BATHSHEBA -) Tomorrow, Fanny, at twelve. And he backs away. FANNY watches him go. For a moment, BATHSHEBA and FANNY’s eyes meet... But TROY is approaching now, eyes black with rage.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Do you know who that woman was?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Get back in the carriage.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Who is she? And now he grabs her wrist, pulls her towards the carriag violent, public too.  113 114 115 116 117 118 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 71

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: How dare you spy on me. Get back in the carriage - (grabs her wrist, pulls her away) Back in the carriage, damn you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so, exhausted and pale, FANNY begins her long journey towards BUDMOUTH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An autumn rain starts to fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. FANNY stirs from uneasy rest. No time to rest or shelter now. She struggles to her feet, steps back out in the rain and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grim, grey building, its iron gates forbidding in the gloom. FANNY reaches for the wall to steady herself, stumbles, falls, lies there in the rain. A light appears in a window. An alarm bell is rung...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATHSHEBA lies on one of the bed, TROY on the other, shirtless, smoking a cheroot. She watches his back. He st out his cheroot. Unbearable tension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATHSHEBA eats breakfast alone. TROY strides in.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Could you let me have twenty pounds?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I need twenty pounds.  119 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 72

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: If you continue to gamble, I will lose the farm.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: It's not for gambling. Do you have the money or not?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: That money is required for farm expenses. She returns to her breakfast. TROY looks dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: You’ve had your fun. Now don’t do something you’ll regret.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I already have.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: What do you regret?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: That our love is at an end.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Well, all love ends at marriage.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I wish you wouldn't talk like that.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I believe you hate me.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I hate your vices.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Then give me the twenty pounds and perhaps we can be friends. Stung, she holds her nerve -—

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: The money is required for farm expenses. A direct challenge. Then he stands and walks determinedly towards the study. BATHSHEBA, enraged, follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TROY strides towards the bureau.  120 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 73

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: It’s for that woman, isn’t it? Tell me her name! He begins to rifle through the drawers, a thief now.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: I will not-

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Is she married? -

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: No -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Is she the one you spoke about, the other woman? Who is she?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: The woman I love! The woman I should have married instead of you! (back to the drawers, scrabbling for the money) There, you’ve wormed it out of me, I hope it makes you happy... (He finds the money.) And if you regret our marriage, then you can be damn sure so do I.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: But I don’t! I don’t regret it if you still love me! I still love you, Frank... (Desperate, holding him) Come to bed, let me try and please you like I used to. I still love you, Frank. Say you love me too! Say it, Frank, and kiss me! He regards her face with a look of appalling scorn, then pushes her away from him.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Bathsheba, please. Don’t be so sentimental. He pockets the money and goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad to be free, glad to be making amends, TROY rides at speed to the rendezvous.  121 122 123 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 74

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TROY waits anxiously at the appointed time for his rendez with FANNY. A rumble. Along the road comes a waggon bearing a COFFIN. pine, a pauper’s casket, a WORKHOUSE OFFICIAL driving. As matter of course, TROY removes his hat out of respect...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cart continues on its way. In the distance, its destination - the EVERDENE FARM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GABRIEL and the WORKHOUSE OFFICIAL are in discussion as BATHSHEBA approaches.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Well there must be some mistake.

dialogues.speaker: WORKHOUSE OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: No mistake, Mr Oak. This was Miss Robbin’s last known abode.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: No, you'll have to take her to the church.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Bring her inside.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Perhaps we might let her rest in the coach-house, ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: We’1ll do no such thing. Fanny was my uncle’s servant and we shall treat her with respect. Bring her inside please. Pale, troubled, BATHSHEBA heads into the house. GABRIEL climbs the waggon, removes the black cloth, and starts— On the lid he sees words written in chalk; ‘FANNY ROBBIN AND CHILD’ He glances towards BATHSHEBA, waiting at the doorway. A moment’s thought. She can’t know. GABRIEL takes his handkerchief and removes the words ‘AND CHILD’  124

dialogues.speaker: 124A
dialogues.text: FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 75

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surrounded by candles, resting on two benches, the coffin sits in the solemn room. BATHSHEBA and LIDDY, with some reverence, place flowers and branches around the plain pauper’s coffin.

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Do you want me any longer ma’am?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: No more tonight, Liddy.

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: I’‘1l wait up if you like.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: No, you go to bed. (LIDDY stands) Do you know what she died of, Liddy?

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: No, miss. There were rumours but...no.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I see. Liddy, Fanny had a sweetheart. Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: (LIDDY hesitates.) Yes, miss. A soldier. A sergeant. (An admission from Liddy. And now she knows) Please, come sit upstairs with me. BATHSHEBA shakes her head - she is crying quietly

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I seem to cry a great deal these days. I never used to cry at all. Good night Liddy. And somewhat reluctantly, LIDDY goes, leaving BATHSHEBA alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Midnight. BATHSHEBA, pacing up and down. She removes the boughs and flowers from the coffin lid. She sees Fanny’s name, and the smudged chalk beneath. Her worst fears... She finds the nails that hold the rough lid down. A momen  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 76 Then she takes the poker from the fireplace, places it beneath the lid, pushes. She stumbles back. The coffin lies open in the darkness. hands shaking, she reaches for a candle and walks towards coffin. FANNY looks beautiful in the candle light. In her arms, a bundle confirms BATHSHEBA’s suspicions. She takes the flo with which she was adorning the coffin, and now places th on her rival's body... Suddenly -

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: What? BATHSHEBA stumbles backwards.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I must go.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I can’t stay. Let me go, I want air.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Stay here! Numb, dazed, TROY crosses and sees his beloved’s face. In arms, the bundle of white linen. He reaches for the linen reveals the face. A thunderbolt of shame and remorse.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Is it her?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: It is. A boy. I had a son. My son. TROY crumples, tears forming in his eyes; shock and grief remorse.

dialogues.speaker: TROY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Forgive me... And as BATHSHEBA looks on, he bends and kisses the lips o his dead fiancee. It’s a kiss you might give to a sleepin child, one of surpassing tenderness. BATHSHEBA is heartbroken.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Frank. Don’t kiss them, I can’t bear it. I love you more than she did!  125 126 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 77

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Bathsheba, this woman is more to me dead than ever were or are or can ever be. You are nothing to me now. Nothing. Heartbroken, BATHSHEBA staggers out -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coffin is loaded onto a hearse. TROY steps from the house. His farmer’s clothes have been discarded in favour of his old uniform; the vivid scarlet jacket. He carries a small suitcase and the sword. He loo broken, haunted, a deeply changed man. He takes one last look at the farmhouse that has felt lik prison, then closes the door. Turning, GABRIEL is there. The men stand firm. An acknowledgement of each other. No affection, but no hosti either. If anything, there’s a sense of TROY handing something back.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Mr Oak. A salute perhaps? GABRIEL nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early morning, a light rain falling, the end of a long, d night of the soul. Shivering, wet hair clinging to her face, BATHSHEBA sits beneath an old oak, overlooking the farm that she inherit with such hope and spirit just nine months ago. Now all s feels is weariness, a great melancholy. She sees a figure striding up the hill towards her, hoppi and sliding through the mud.

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: There you are! Oh, Miss, whatever are you thinking? You'll catch your death.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Is he at home?

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Gone, Miss, with Fanny. The money too. (LIDDY embrace BATHSHEBA) I’ve come to take you home.  127 128 129 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 78

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Liddy, will you promise me something?

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Don’t ever marry.

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Not much chance of that, between the ugly ones I won’t have and the handsome ones who won’t have me.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Well if you do find someone, stand firm. When trouble comes your way, and it will, don’t run from it. Stand your ground, even if you’re cut to pieces. That’s what I intend to do. And they start to walk towards the farm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A new slab of white marble. The new grave, with new heads now in place. A simple inscription; Erected by Francis Troy. In loving memory of Fanny Robbin Child. TROY takes all the money he has and pays the STONEMASON.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: There you are. That’s everything. Alone now, he tends to the rough grave as best he can, planting it with wild flowers, a little garden for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The road to the coast. TROY walks with determination towa a new, as yet unknown life. It's the last warm day of the year and hot and tired, he stops. In the distance, the sea shimmers invitingly. TROY thinks for a moment, then changes direction, and heads towards the coast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A deserted, sandy cove, concealed from view by a semi-cir of high rocks.  130 158 131 132 133 134 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 79 TROY’s possessions, folded and stacked with military precision, lie on the beach. The sword glints in the sun. TROY sits, naked, and contemplates the sea. Then he stand and runs into the waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TROY pounding away from the shore, attempting to wash awa the past in the cold sea water. Breathless, he stops and turns. The beach is somehow a li further away than he thought. He must have been caught by tide. He starts to pound back towards the shore. But the shore is no nearer. If anything it’s suddenly fur away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO BOYS run on the beach. One of them comes across the suitcase and uniform, the thrilling sword. Curious, they stoop and examine it more closely. EXT. THE SEA — DAY 132 TROY can see the tiny figures on the beach. Treading wate he starts to shout and wave...

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Hello! Over here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scarlet jacket is held aloft, the sword is pulled fro its scabbard. It glints in the evening sun. The sight is intoxicating for the BOYS. As the sun sets, they play at soldiers at the water's edg sword slicing through driftwood while out to sea, TROY’s figure is lost in the waves, his voice unheard... EXT. THE SEA — DAY 134 From far out to sea, TROY watches the boys playing at soldiers. There’s a strange calm in his eyes. And he starts to swim again, this time away from the shore.  135 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 80

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATHSHEBA is at work again in the halls of the Corn Excha But the CUSTOMERS who once flocked to her now pass her by She notes the disapproving looks, the gossip. An abandoned wife, her husband the father of an illegitim child. There’s a cloud of scandal, disapproval, which she accepts with as much dignity as she can. And now TWO MEN are approaching her, a CONSTABLE and a SOLICITOR. All eyes on her now -

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLE
dialogues.text: Mrs Troy?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: It's about my husband, isn’t it? Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: SOLICITOR
dialogues.text: I’m afraid...I’m afraid your husband has drowned. BATHSHEBA staggers from the blow.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: It’s not true. It can’t be. And now BOLDWOOD is approaching, arriving just as she collapses.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: What did you say to her, man?

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLE
dialogues.text: Her husband is dead. Drowned at sea. No glee from BOLDWOOD, a man of action and decision now. scoops her up, carrying her through the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Some air! Gentlemen, some air please. Make way! (BATHSHEBA, recovering now, stirs) You've had the most terrible shock. My carriage is outside, I'll take you home -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: No, put me down please. He does so immediately.  136 137 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 81

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: You’re hardly in a condition to drive yourself -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Please, Mr Boldwood. I'd like to go home alone. And she gathers herself and walks, a little unsteadily, towards the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sombre mood at the farm. A pale of black water. LIDDY h up BATHSHEBA’s scarlet dress.

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: You’1l need something to wear, it’s only proper. Miss?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: No. It’s not necessary.

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Why not, ma’‘am?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Because he’s still alive.

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Oh, Miss...

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Wouldn’t I know more, and wouldn’t they have found him, and wouldn't death feel...different to this?

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: It’s only natural to hope. But still - BATHSHEBA hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Very well. The dress is immersed in the black water. And now hangs up to dry, dripping black dye on the ground

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown-paper packages.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 82 BATHSHEBA, austerely beautiful and pale in the black of h mourning dress, opens it; his jacket, his sword - all his possessions, retrieved from the beach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GABRIEL returns from a day in the fields to find MR BOLDW waiting near the entrance. Bright, cheerful -

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Mr Oak, I wonder if I could have a word.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: It's a great responsibility, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Nonsense! No reason why a man of your abilities should not be able to superintend two farms. And why shouldn’t there be stronger links between our establishments? Think of it; two thousand acres under your sole charge, a share of my profits...

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Miss Everdene needs me here.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: And her farm would have priority. He sees BATHSHEBA, holding back, watching. There’s someth gleeful about BOLDWOOD here, as if holding something back

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: I would need Miss Everdene’s permission.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: But of course. I wouldn’t dare to do anything without her blessing. (GABRIEL contemplates) If it helps sway your decision, there’s an old colleague of yours here - He opens a side door and out bounds - OLD GEORGE. GABRIEL can’t help but laugh as the dog bound into his arms. BOLDWOOD watches with pleasure.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 83

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He took some finding, Mr Oak. I hope you’re pleased.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: I am, sir. Very much.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: And you'll give me your decision soon. Yes? BATHSHEBA watches too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATHSHEBA and GABRIEL are sheltering from the rain in the doorway. OLD GEORGE is there too - a memory of past times

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Farmer Oak, you're getting on in the world. I knew you would.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Only with your approval. You know where my loyalty lies -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: You’re a man of great talent, it’s only natural that you should rise. I’ve no desire to hold you back. She smiles sadly, and he watches her go. Something has be lost; her arrogance and vanity, but also her spirit and exuberance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the demands of farming are constant, and as late AUTU passes into early WINTER, BATHSHEBA works away in the fie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and falls asleep, exhausted, fully-clothed, alone in th big old house -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hymn. In the church, much has changed. GABRIEL has join MR BOLDWOOD in the private pews. In smart Sunday clothes, gathers many admiring glances. BOLDWOOD, too, has lifted his spirits, singing out loud.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 84 BATHSHEBA, pale in her mourning black, keeps her eyes forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATHSHEBA is out hunting. Pheasants move in the undergrow and she raises her gun to take aim... But a noise startles them - they fly off, and she turns a sees BOLDWOOD approaching on horseback. An accidental encounter.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Mr Boldwood.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Mrs Troy.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: We’ve not spoken since -

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: No. We’ve not.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I was heading home, if you’d like to...but perhaps you’re busy.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: No. I’d like that. Very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit, companionably, taking tea.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: You were very kind to me that day. I hope you’ll forgive me if I’ve kept a certain distance. I’ve been..not my old self.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: No. (a delicate matter) Forgive me, I understand there are debts.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: You’ve heard then -

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Your late husband -  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 85

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Perhaps we should change the subject -

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Perhaps I can help.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Mr Boldwood, that’s a kind offer, but I would never dream of borrowing -

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Not money. (He's trying to restrain himself. But no good - ) I’m a middle-aged man willing to protect you for the rest of your life. You may run your farm if you wish, without risk. I'll pay your departed husband’s debts and guarantee its financial stability. It can be your pastime. Of course, we'd need to wait, for propriety’s sake. But when you are ready, I’m offering you shelter, comfort. A safe harbour. As my wife. (a beat) You must at least admire my persistence. She smiles at this.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I do -

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: And like me?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Yes -

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: And respect me?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Yes, of course -—

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Which is it, like or respect?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I..it is difficult for a woman to define her feelings in language that is made by men to express theirs. I know I do not love you. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 86

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know that I can never love you the way a woman ought to love her husband.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: If you worry about a lack of passion on your part, a lack of...desire, if you worry about marrying me merely out of guilt and pity and compromise, well - I don’t mind. I love you and, for my own part, I’m content merely to be liked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATHSHEBA and GABRIEL, wrapped up against the chill night stand shoulder to shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: When must you give your answer?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: By Christmas. It’s a terrible responsibility, to hold a man’s happiness in your hands. His sanity too, perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Could you...care for him?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: You mean love him? Let’s just say...love is wanting. But then love’s a worn-out, miserable thing for me now, love for him or anyone. And perhaps a marriage without love is the price I have to pay. It’s too much for GABRIEL.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Why are you asking me? Why not ask Liddy or the parson -?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I need someone who’s clear-headed, who's objective, indifferent...

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Then I’m afraid you ask the wrong man. And there it is. An admission. She does not answer immediately.  145 146 147 148 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 87

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Well...thank you, Mr Oak - She stands, smiles sadly. And walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TRAVELLER walks along a deserted country road. The over and uniform he wears - an ordinary merchant navy seaman’ somewhat bedraggled and muddied, and the face is unshaven but he’s still recognisable as FRANCIS TROY. A cart approaches. He waits until it’s near then hails th DRIVER.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Can you take me to Weatherbury? (the DRIVER rides on. TROY’s most charming smile -) It is Christmas. The DRIVER slows TROY jumps on the rear of the cart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Axes thud into wood. A great pine is felled by WORKMEN as BOLDWOOD looks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The steam tractor drags the immense tree towards BOLDWOOD mansion. INT. GREAT HALL, BOLDWOOD’S MANSION - DAY 148 The great tree stands in the process of decoration. Christmas Eve preparations. A table is laid with meats, w bread, even fruit. In pride of place - a pineapple! BOLDWOOD presides over it all, glowing with hope and excitement, a little manic perhaps as he shows GABRIEL around.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: So - what do you think? (the room) I’m not in the habit of organising parties. Perhaps we should make it an annual event, every Christmas Eve. I’ve invited the whole village, do you think they’1l come? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 88

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you think Miss Everdene will come?

dialogues.speaker: OAK
dialogues.text: I’m sure she will. Fussing in a mirror, he attempts adjust his tie, while GABRIEL looks on.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: You’1l stay too I hope? I know Miss Everdene would like you to be here.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Perhaps. For an hour or so.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Look - my hands are shaking I’m so nervous. Gabriel, would you? As well as you can, please. (GABRIEL takes the tie. Face to face -) Is there a knot that’s particularly in fashion?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: You’re asking the wrong man.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: What about women? Does a woman keep her promise?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: She has promised?

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: An implied promise.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Once again, I’m not the best person to -

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: But will she do what’s right?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: If it’s not inconvenient to her.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Oak, you've become quite cynical lately! She never promised me that first time, therefore she has never broken her promise.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: She hasn’t promised this time either.  149 150 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 89

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: But she will tonight, I know she will. And when she does - He produces a small box from his pocket. An engagement ri heavy with diamonds. GABRIEL can’t speak. BOLDWOOD (CONT’D) I wanted to tell you in advance, Gabriel, because I believe I know your secret. (an awkward stab at intimacy) I’ve seen you together, the way you speak to her and watch her and look after her. And I know of her profound...affection for you. You've behaved like a man and as the successful rival - successful through your kindness - I wish you to know that I am profoundly grateful. And BOLDWOOD beams tearfully in gratitude for the final fulfilment of his dream. Then -

dialogues.speaker: BUTLER
dialogues.text: The musicians are here, Sir. The BUTLER departs. To GABRIEL;

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Please - stay. Celebrate with us. EXT. BOLDWOOD’S MANSION - NIGHT 149 Lit by torches, the exterior of the mansion looks magnificent. MUSIC can be heard. The party has already started, and BATHSHEBA, descending from the carriage, beautiful in a black silk dress, looks up at the house wi terrible sense of foreboding. At some point this may well be her new home. It’s a fine house, yet she can barely bring herself to step inside. She takes LIDDY’s hand, squeezes it, and they head in. INT. GREAT HALL, BOLDWOOD’S MANSION - NIGHT 150 The Party. There are a great many GUESTS here, largely lo GENTRY and FARMERS but, in the spirit of Christmas, some the WORKERS too, all of whom are making the most of the f and the wine. JOSEPH, JACOB, JAN and BILLY, all in their Sunday best, all in various stages of inebriation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 151 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 90 The band PLAYS. The dancing has just begin - rather forma and reserved at present. BATHSHEBA’s arrival, though, is enough to draw the other GUEST’s attention. The beautiful widow, still a source of fascination. From his vantage point on the great stairs, BOLDWOOD watc BATHSHEBA arrives. She smiles back, a little awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shadow in the hallway. TROY, alone, in his old home. He looks through cupboards and drawers. On a shelf, a gli of red. Through torn brown paper, his cavalry jacket, his sword. All his possessions, retrieved from the beach. INT. GREAT HALL, BOLDWOOD’S MANSION - NIGHT 151 The PARTY continues, the wine taking effect. Dancing has started, and BOLDWOOD, still keeping his distance, is urg people to join in the merriment. BATHSHEBA, sitting apart, watches him. An effort of imagination; her future husband, her future home. GABRIEL, in turn, is the centre of attention. TWO FARMER’ DAUGHTERS, working away at him. But his eyes are on BATHSHEBA, and her sadness. She catches his eye, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Will you excuse me - - and he crosses to her, leaving his ADMIRERS sadly alone

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Mr Oak, you've broken their hearts - (the ADMIRERS) Go back and talk to them, poor things -

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: I’ve come to say goodnight. I don’t suit this kind of affair.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: No, neither do I. I wish I could leave too.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Stay a little longer. For his sake. Both look to BOLDWOOD the buoyant host.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 91

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I’ve been trying to imagine myself living here. I can’t seem to manage it.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: You’d suit it very well.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Would I? A sad smile, a moment between them, interrupted by BOLDWO

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: I must go.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Not before you’ve danced, both of you. I insist.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Mr Oak? Hesitation, then GABRIEL offers his hand. They take to th floor, and join the other DANCERS. The dance is by no means intimate or improper. There’s a distance between them at all times, and LIDDY, BOLDWOOD, GUESTS watch it with pleasure. But for GABRIEL and BATHSHEBA it is a kind of agony. BATHSHEBA (CONT’D) Gabriel. Tell me - what am I going to do? GABRIEL thinks about this. He sees BOLDWOOD watching them the smile on his face, the ring in his pocket. He can’t answer. BATHSHEBA looks to him - BATHSHEBA (CONT’D) Gabriel?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Do what is right. BATHSHEBA struggles to accept the truth of this, and to h her disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, of course. She nods tearfully, breaks away and heads for the door. BOLDWOOD sees her and follows, GABRIEL watching them go.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 92 152 INT. STAIRWAY, BOLDWOOD’S MANSION - NIGHT 152

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Mrs Troy, surely you’re not leaving?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Yes, I should like to go now-

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: But your promise! You said by Christmas -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Yes I did.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: My proposal, you accept it? (she hesitates) A business contract, between two friends free of passion or sentiment. I deserve it. A deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I give my promise, yes. I give it as the payment of a debt.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: When enough time has passed, you'll marry me? Yes? (She nods.) Say the words.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I will marry you. BOLDWOOD’s face lights up. Wild-eyed joy.

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Thank you! Thank you, thank you, thank you, God bless you, Bathsheba-

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Now I must go-

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: One more thing-

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Please, Mr Boldwood-

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: (the ring) You’1l take this. As a token of my love-  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 93

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I cannot wear a ring, it is not right, it is too soon -

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: Just for tonight. For me. BATHSHEBA takes in the man, his look of total adoration. relents and holds out her hand. To her discomfort, BOLDWOOD slides on the ring, then kiss her hand. BOLDWOOD (CONT’D) Finally. I am happy now. 153 EXT. BOLDWOOD’S MANSION - NIGHT 153 BATHSHEBA hurries out into the night, desperate to get aw She slows, and STOPS. On the great lawn, lit by flaming torches, the STRANGEST SIGHT. A FIGURE stands in the moonlight, scarlet and silver, a s in his hand as he practices the sword drill. It might alm be a ghost. 154 INT. GREAT HALL, BOLDWOOD’S MANSION - NIGHT 154 GABRIEL is pulling on his coat, leaving now. LIDDY rushes to him, drunk, flirtatious.

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Mr Oak, no more excuses, you'll dance with me now.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Have you seen Mrs Troy?

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: (disappointed) I think she may have left. 155 EXT. BOLDWOOD’S MANSION - NIGHT 155 TROY and BATHSHEBA face to face, TROY a little drunk now, dishevelled, unshaven.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Frank.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Black suits you. A little premature, I'm afraid.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 94

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I knew it, I knew you were alive, I felt it.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: And here I am. Some fishermen pulled me from the sea. Then I discovered I was dead, and found that I preferred it, for a while anyway.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: So why have you come back, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: The strangest thing. I found I missed you. What’s the matter? You don’t seem very pleased to see me. No kiss after all this time?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: You said that I was dead to you.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Did I? Well, then - honesty at all times. I find myself in need of money. I gave up my profession for you, it seems harsh that you should have a house and farm while I’m living hand to mouth.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: There is no money -

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Then we’ll sell the farm. BATHSHEBA stands numb, devastated - finally defeated. Near the house a few FIGURES can be seen. GUESTS from the party, SPECTATORS, incredulous at the sight.

dialogues.speaker: TROY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come my love, no tears. Come home with me. We’ll talk like we used to. (BATHSHEBA doesn’t move) Did you hear what I said? Come. (No reply) I’M YOUR HUSBAND AND YOU’LL OBEY

dialogues.speaker: ME, DAMNIT
dialogues.text: Furious, he reaches for her hand and grabs it - He sees the engagement ring glittering there. A realisati the truth dawning. TROY smiles, and -—  156 157 158 159 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 95 An EXPLOSION. A gunshot. The force of the blast is immens sending TROY sprawling across the lawn, the full force of shotgun blast directed straight into his chest. BOLDWOOD stands, gun in hand. BATHSHEBA’s face, her dress are sprayed with blood. She starts to shake. OTHER GUESTS come running -

dialogues.speaker: BOLDWOOD
dialogues.text: I won’t be robbed again. Not again. He gives the gun to GABRIEL. Then, with calm simplicity, approaches BATHSHEBA, takes her hand, kisses it - Then BOLDWOOD walks away. FADE TO BLACK. INT. GREAT HALL, BOLDWOOD’S MANSION - DAY 156 GABRIEL walks through the great hall, empty now. The Christmas tree stands forlorn and wilted. INT. BEDROOM, BOLDWOOD’S MANSION - DAY 157 GABRIEL pulls open the wardrobe. Dresses in every colour the rainbow, silks and satins, poplins and serges, all re for his beloved fiancee... Stitched into a pair of white calf-skin gloves, a label b the name - ‘Bathsheba Boldwood.’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfectly calm, BOLDWOOD sits erect in his cell, hands in lap. Strangely peaceful and still at last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grey January day, and rain falls on TROY’s funeral. His friend and comrade-in-arms SERGEANT DOGGETT and a small scattering of military men represent his former regiment. BATHSHEBA stands a little way off, dressed in black, in mourning for the second time. The inscription on the gravestone now reads - Erected by Francis Troy. In loving memory of Fanny Robbin Child. Died October 9th.  160 161 162 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 96 In the same grave lies the aforesaid Francis Troy, Who Di December 24th. INT. BEDROOM, BOLDWOOD’S MANSION - DAY 160 GABRIEL opens a drawer. Jewellery; diamonds, pearls, rubi heavy gold bracelets.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Let me see. REVEAL BATHSHEBA, in mourning, as she steps forward ginge and takes in the jewellery. She takes something from her pocket. The engagement ring BOLDWOOD gave her.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: If it’s any consolation, his life will be spared. A crime of passion.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Because of me.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: You did the right thing in the end. BATHSHEBA puts the engagement ring back in amongst the ot jewels. GABRIEL pushes the drawer closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Summer again. Another harvest. The fields are full of WOR scything the corn - a fine harvest, a flourishing busines Still in mourning black, BATHSHEBA watches, and allows herself a smile of satisfaction. Music continues -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The choir is practicing in the church nearby as BATHSHEBA tends her husband's grave. She is still in mourning, but some of the colour has retu to her face now; not quite the firebrand of the last year but not so drawn and haunted. She becomes aware of a figure behind her; GABRIEL.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 97

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I startled you.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I wanted to tend their grave. I've not been here for so long. (the church) Are you going in?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Rehearsals. I sing bass in the choir.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Yes, I’ve heard you.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Then I apologise. (she smiles) I’'d been hoping for a chance to talk to you. We’ve not spoken as much as I'd have liked -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: No -

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: And I wanted an opportunity to say...well, the fact is I’m leaving England.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Leaving?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: To go to America. I’ve a mind to try California, and there’s a boat leaving Bristol. Four day’s time. I’1l be on it. (She’s struggling to take this all in. ) I understand that I should give you notice.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: No, you must go when you want.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Then I’1l leave first thing in the morning. No fuss. I think that’s best. And BATHSHEBA stands, shell-shocked in the graveyard as GABRIEL walks away. The choir sings. She is struggling to take this all in.  163 164 165 166

dialogues.speaker: 166B
dialogues.text: FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 98

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATHSHEBA sits on the edge of the bed. She hasn’t slept a wink. She stands, opens the window, looks out at her land. Her wardrobe. Her dress of mourning black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No longer dressed in black, BATHSHEBA sits at the table, attempting to sort through the accounts. LIDDY and OLD GEORGE are there too, LIDDY, tearful, conso the dog, sniffing, inconsolable at the news.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Liddy, that’s enough.

dialogues.speaker: LIDDY
dialogues.text: Sorry, Miss. BATHSHEBA returns to the papers before her. Staring. Unseeing. Suddenly she pushes her chair back, walks from the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATHSHEBA mounts her horse, determined, a decision made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATHSHEBA rides and rides, just as we first saw her. Cres a hill, she searches the western road ahead, searching fo GABRIEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spot where she found him before, but no sign of him t time. Is she too late? She urges the horse on -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes to a halt. Losing hope now. Then - a figure, fa off. It can only be GABRIEL. She rides on -  167 FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 99

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GABRIEL walks on, his possessions on his back. The sun is setting now, but he doesn’t look back, not even when he h the sound of horses hooves behind him.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Gabriel! Gabriel, wait! (she dismounts, breathless) You’1l think I’m strange, but...I thought..I wanted to know.. Gabriel, have I offended you?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: No -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: - or upset you in some way?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Is it money? I will pay you more, Gabriel, whatever you want.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: I don’t need money now.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: A formal partnership then?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: +..nor a partnership. The farm belongs to you alone. The finest farm for miles around.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Then why are you going? A moment.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: I said I’d leave you one day.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I had hoped I could change your mind.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Not this time.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Well you must not go!

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: You forbid me?  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 100

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Yes, if you like! I forbid you!

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: (he smiles) It's time for you to fight your own battles, and win them too. I believe in you entirely. I don’t believe there’s anything you can’t do. And that’s the end of the discussion.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: So we should say goodbye then.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: I suppose so.

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Thank you, Gabriel. You’ve believed in me and fought for me and stood by my side when all the world was against me, and we’ve been through so much together - Wasn’t I your first sweetheart? Weren’t you mine? - and now to have to carry on without you when I’ve loved you for so long - (and there it is) I love you, Gabriel. There. A moment —

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: If I knew -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: If I knew that you would let me love you and marry you -

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: - but you’ll never know.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Because you never ask!

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: Would you say no again?

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Probably.

dialogues.speaker: 167B
dialogues.text: FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 101 GABRIEL can’t help himself. He laughs, and she laughs too BATHSHEBA (CONT’D) So why don’t you, Gabriel? Ask me now. Ask me! A moment and then he steps towards her, takes her in his and kisses her. And then -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in the church, GABRIEL and BATHSHEBA at the altar, smart but not over-dressed, GABRIEL immensely proud.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIEL
dialogues.text: I will. The VICAR turns to BATHSHEBA -

dialogues.speaker: VICAR
dialogues.text: Wilt thou have this man to thy wedded husband? In the small but happy congregation, LIDDY, the MEN, MRS HURST. But our attention is on BATHSHEBA, C.U., listening intently.

dialogues.speaker: VICAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wilt thou obey him, and serve him, love, honour and keep him in sickness and in health? This is not just a conventional form of words, but a sole vow and she weighs each part. Obey, serve, love, honour..

dialogues.speaker: VICAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And forsaking all others, keep thee only to him, so long as you both shall live? A suspended moment. A decision. And then, finally, with joy and conviction, an affirmatio

dialogues.speaker: BATHSHEBA
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors of the church - - burst open as the CONGREGATION spills out. All the work are there - LIDDY laughing and crying at the same time, M HURST too. Not a grand marriage, but a joyous celebration none the less. A ramshackle procession forms, heading dow the country lane.  FFMC Shooting Script Sept 2013 102 And at the rear walk the bride and groom. BATHSHEBA takes GABRIEL’s arm, and rests her head on her husband’s shoulder. FADE OUT.
